Headline: Kenya Airways Plane Crashed In S Cameroon-State Radio -2-
Story: Kenya Airways said earlier Saturday it had lost contact with the plane shortly after takeoff.   "The last message was received in Douala after takeoff and thereafter the tower was unable to contact the plane," Kenya Airways CEO Titus Naikuni said in the Kenyan capital.   The Boeing 737-800 was carrying 106 passengers, eight crew members and a flight engineer, he said. The plane can carry 189 passengers.   The flight departed Douala, Cameroon, at 12:05 a.m. and was to arrive in Nairobi, the Kenyan capital, at 6:15 a.m. The flight originated in Ivory Coast but stopped in Cameroon to pick up more passengers, the airline said.   The airline opened a crisis management center near the Nairobi airport. Relatives of those on the plane were instructed to go to a downtown Nairobi airport, where they would be provided information as it became available.   The last crash of an international Kenya Airways flight was on Jan. 30, 2000, when Flight 431 was taking off from Abidjan, Ivory Coast, on its way to Nairobi. Investigators blamed a faulty alarm and pilot error for that crash, which killed 169 people.       On the Internet: http://www.kenya-airways.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 04:56 ET (08:56 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) What The Press Release Won't Say
Story: (From BARRON'S)   Some investors will be surprised Monday if iMergent, a controversial Amex-listed provider of e-commerce business software and services, announces "blow-out" earnings for its January-March quarter. Others will be even more surprised if it doesn't.   Over the past few weeks, Barron's has learned, iMergent's CEO, Donald L. Danks, has told select individual and institutional investors that the company's fiscal third-quarter earnings will beat the estimate of 39-to-41 cents a share set by the one analyst who follows the company by better than 50%. That translates into about 60 cents a share, versus 29 cents in the comparable 2006 period.   Some people apparently have gotten the good word already. On a tape recording of a conversation heard by Barron's, a voice that sounds like Danks' is heard telling an investor about the earnings, adding that "net dollar contracts written," which is the way the company reports its revenue, will be around $50 million, versus $26 million.   The recording was made by a person who says he took part in the conversation, who identifies the other speaker as Danks and who contends that others have told him they have had similar discussions with the iMergent CEO. Such conversations would appear to violate Regulation FD of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which mandates that a company can't disclose material information about its operations selectively, but instead must make "fair disclosure" to all potentially interested parties -- investors, analysts, brokers -- simultaneously.   Asked about this Friday afternoon, Danks adamantly denied having spoken with any outsiders about the quarterly earnings. "I would never give that information to anyone who would use it to trade the stock."   On the recording, the voice that sounds like Danks' tells the other person that a Barron's reporter has contacted him and appears to be working on a positive article about the company.   Barron's also has learned that analyst Michael E. Shonstrom, who follows iMergent for Emerging Growth Equities, a securities firm in King of Prussia, Pa., has alerted some clients that, based on information from the company, he expects better results than he had forecast. The company has not publicly made such a statement.   In an April 24 e-mail supporting his 12-month price target of $36 and Buy recommendation for iMergent (ticker: IIG), which late last week traded around 25.50, Shonstrom advised one client that his previously published estimates for 2007's March and June quarters were "conservative," based on new data from the company. His e-mail reads in part: " . . . in conversations with management, they note that the 9th seminar [sales] team has started off very strongly and that consumer response rates continue to exceed prior metrics . . . ."   Neither his description of the results of the sales team nor data about the firm's key metric, which measures the percentage of customers who buy products at iMergent seminars, were mentioned in a research report issued April 30, about a week after the private investor received the e-mail. In February, Shonstrum and Danks appeared on CNBC, extolling the stock and deriding shorts for "ganging up" on it.   Asked about the April 24 e-mail, the analyst says: I don't think it constitutes inside information because [it does] say 'based on conversations with management.' In general, all that I am saying is that they are reiterating what they said at the quarter conference call."   The person who says he tape-recorded his conversation with Danks is short iMergent stock, meaning he's sold borrowed shares in the hope that the price will fall, letting him replace them with shares costing less.   Why, then, would Danks, who presumably would like the shares to rise -- he owns more than 500,000 -- speak with this person? Probably because this individual previously was long the stock, viewing it as undervalued, and hadn't told Danks that he'd changed his view. He'd turned into a bear after becoming suspicious of the company's business model and fearful that iMergent ultimately would collapse.   Since the end of the company's third fiscal quarter, on March 31, the shares have risen 30%. The advance has come despite the absence of positive news and in the face of an SEC investigation into iMergent's accounting, plus legal problems on other fronts.   The company, whose headquarters are in Orem, Utah, stages more than 1,000 day-long seminars each year in the U.S. and abroad through its StoresOnline unit. These seminars are aimed at would-be Internet entrepreneurs. Those who sign up pay, on average, $5,000 and a small monthly fee to iMergent for such things as software to run their Websites, Web-hosting services and advice on online commerce.   IMergent has been under heavy attack for the past year by short sellers. They've made massive bets that its shares will drop amid the SEC accounting probe, which began in 2005, and private and public lawsuits alleging that the company engages in fraudulent, unfair practices.   Illinois is suing iMergent in Madison County, Ill., Circuit Court, alleging that it misled workshop participants about the ease of using its e-commerce software and the availability of technical support. Illinois officials want the company to stop selling or promoting its products in the state. Through an attorney, the company calls the charges "unwarranted."   A spokeswoman for the Florida state attorney general's office says it is pursuing an "active investigation" of iMergent. And, Barron's has learned, investigations of iMergent's business practices are at early stages in Oregon and Maryland.   The company has already paid hundreds of thousands of dollars in refunds and legal expenses to defend itself against charges of deceiving consumers (see the box below) in Texas, California, Indiana and Australia.   In addition, sometime in the next few days -- possibly Wednesday -- Utah could deal the company a potentially heavy blow. Its consumer-protection division is expected to designate iMergent as a "business opportunity" provider. That designation would force the company to disclose how much money its customers make from their Websites, how many sites are running, how many are hosted by StoresOnline, and other sensitive financial information that the company claims it doesn't have or doesn't want to reveal for competitive reasons. Danks pledges that he'd fight such a designation "all the way to the Supreme Court, if necessary."   If the success rate for iMergent's online customers were shown to be unfavorable, the information could devastate the company by discouraging prospective customers from signing up. The shorts obviously view this as a possibility. "The short overhang is incredible," says Jamie Halegoua, head trader and a derivatives expert at Goldsmith & Harris, Wall Street financial consultants. "I've never seen anything like this."   As of March 15, the number of iMergent shares that had been shorted hit a record 7.4 million -- 60% of the 12.4 million outstanding, according Hedge Fund Trades, a Dow Jones online publication. Since then, shorts have suffered more than $50 million in paper losses, the publication says, as the stock has gone up. That's a continuation of an unpleasant trend for the shorts, who've squirmed as the stock has risen over 110% in the past two years, driven by earnings reported to have been growing at a double-digit clip, strong reported cash flow and a net dollar volume of contracts written that bulls believe will grow by more than 50% this year, to over $140 million.   "The company fundamentally has a lot of growth opportunity and new products that will generate significant recurring revenues," says one of those bulls, Brad Halverson, a fund manager with Troy, Mich.-based Northpointe Capital, one of the stock's largest institutional holders. "But no one focuses on that."   What the shorts -- and the SEC -- are focused on is the company's business model and its accounting.   Andrew Left, whose Los Angeles financial Website, Citron Research (formerly Stocklemon.com), has been a persistent thorn in the company's side, says that iMergent uses "cookie-jar accounting to pad current earnings." The company denies that its accounting is improper.   Left and Danks are old adversaries. Left has been short the stock for two years. In 2005, Danks filed a $15 million defamation suit against him and the Website; it was dismissed in 2006. Left says that he recently has been "deluged with anonymous hate e-mail from [iMergent] supporters who have been telling me I am wrong about the company and will be proven so when it reports earnings 50% higher than what's been projected for the third quarter." And, he asks rhetorically: "Where did that number come from?"   Investor and sports mogul Mark Cuban, who owns the NBA's Dallas Mavericks, is another longtime  iMergent bear. Cuban, who once was short the stock but says he no longer is, contends that the company doesn't produce for its customers. "That means it's not a question of if it collapses, but when," he declares.   In 2005, the SEC forced the company to restate its financial data from 2002 to 2005 and change its accounting from an "accrual" to a "cash" system, meaning that it had to recognize revenue after it had been received, rather than when it was expected to materialize. If the company had used cash accounting, profit growth wouldn't have been nearly as robust as it had reported. The restatement turned results for iMergent's 2003 and 2004 fiscal years into losses.   Danks has been reassuring investors that the current SEC probe is basically finished and that the company has been given a clean bill of health. But the agency's recent correspondence with iMergent indicates that the investigation remains ongoing. At issue now is how the company accounts for its contract revenues and its failure to distinguish between cash sales and financed sales. Inclusion of financed sales can paint an overly rosy revenue picture.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Follow-Up: A Charge To Risky Peaks
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Cash is well on its way to being dethroned by plastic, the new king.   That's the inescapable conclusion to be drawn from MasterCard's stupendous surge in profits, reported last week. The credit-card payment processor uncorked a 67% jump in first-quarter earnings per share, to $1.57, demolishing Wall Street's consensus forecast of $1.15. The bottom-line bounty was driven by a 16.4% rise in the dollar volume of card purchases, a 19.4% increase in transactions and 11% growth in the number of cards issued.   MasterCard's shares  jumped more than 17% on the news, to 134, thus proving it still is possible to impress holders of a stock that had nearly tripled from its May 2006 offering price of 39. At current prices, however, buyers might want to think twice before whipping out the plastic to pay for more shares.   Just before its  IPO, Barron's flagged MasterCard, then a cooperative owned by its member banks, as an attractive way to play the global advance of credit- and debit-card use ("Finally Charging Ahead," May 15, 2006). But no one -- us included -- foresaw just how rapidly the company  would be able to accelerate its profit growth. Nor did we expect the stock to ramp to its present lofty valuation, which makes it a much riskier investment than it was a year ago.   At the time of our story, analysts estimated MasterCard would earn $2.20 a share in 2006 and $2.50 this year. Instead the company booked $3.41 a share last year, and the current forecast for 2007 is $4.28.   The lesson: Never underestimate the earnings leverage of a duopoly player converting from a sleepy co-op to a profit-seeking entity.   The  blossoming of earnings expectations, and then some, now is  reflected in MasterCard's stock price. When it first came public,  MasterCard was trading for 17.7 times 2006 profits   and 15.6 times 2007 numbers, based on analysts' estimates at the time. In reality, we know the multiples were far lower, given the company's subsequent profit growth.   Now the stock is trading for more than 29 times this year's estimate and 25 times the 2008 forecast. A year ago, MasterCard traded at a discount to First Data (FDC), a transaction processor with a roughly comparable business. Now, with First Data about to be acquired in a leveraged buyout for $34 a share, that company fetches 23.2 times expected 2008 earnings, a notable discount to MasterCard.   This doesn't mean MasterCard has finished its run, but it does suggest that the company will need to keep beating expectations to support its now-aggressive valuation.   Brisk global economic growth, the long-term trend of plastic replacing cash and the impressive economies of scale enjoyed by MasterCard are all encouraging factors. It's also reassuring that Wall Street isn't wholly enamored of MasterCard shares, even as they continue to hit new highs: A minority of analysts recommend the stock, and there are even four Sell ratings. Short interest, at last report, was also fairly high.   Despite all that, the risk-reward proposition for the stock has eroded in the past year. At the IPO, the Street was consumed with worry over possible legal liabilities from a lawsuit over alleged anticompetitive practices. Today, investors are fixated on the growth story and inattentive toward the legal risks, even as a trial date of September 2008 has been set and the stock's valuation leaves little room for the slightest disappointment.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Streetwise: Curbed Enthusiasm
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   As perennial as the end of April itself, space-filling commentary about the old "Sell in May and go away" market-timing strategy is back.   In years when stocks have been strong heading into May, you often see the subject treated with headlines such as this one: "Wall Street May Not Abide 'Sell in May' Adage." That one was from a newswire dispatch dated April 27 --  of last year.   Citing a well-known investment-advisory firm, the piece featured the quote, "The market has proven to be resilient this year, even amid negatives." Such negatives were said to include high oil prices and a vigilant Federal Reserve. The same could be said about today's situation, almost word for word.   We now know the Dow reached a short-term high on May 5, 2006, before tumbling about 8% into mid-June. It then stabilized and took flight through year end.   In addition to the coincidence of the Dow sitting at a new high on May 5 in each year, there are a few more similarities. This year and last at this time, the S&P 500 was up about 6% year to date. The Dow Transports were at a record in both instances. And the "global economic and liquidity boom" was the dominant cover story for the bullish market action, then and now.   Yet there is a noteworthy difference in the two periods relating to investor psychology and behavior. This year's run to new highs is being met with a bit more skepticism than was last year's. Short interest is appreciably higher, both in absolute terms and as a proportion of overall trading volume.   Other indicators of investors' gut feel are dissonant, but on balance folks appear less giddy now, a modest net positive for the market. There has been a divergence in investor sentiment between professional investors and the retail set for a long time, and currently it is rather pronounced.   Surveys that ask active pros what they think have showed steady if not extreme bullishness, and long-only fund managers are and have been "all in," with cash levels at stock funds reported last week to have fallen to a record low of 3.7%. One notable exception to this outburst of optimism: the latest Barron's Big Money poll, featured in last week's issue.   The American Association of Individual Investors poll, on the other hand, dipped below 35% bulls last week, a level breached only nine times in the past 15 years -- and only once after the market posted a gain in the prior month. Clearly, the broad populace is fighting the market trend.   None of this insulates the market from succumbing to what most would consider an overdue pullback of some variety, with nearly all buying interest in the past few weeks concentrated in the shares of buyout candidates (real or imagined) and companies that just pulverized -- and not merely beat -- earnings expectations.   But the abiding reluctance of the public to get excited about stocks in the face of record Dow highs and manic merger activity implies that a correction would probably stop short of being "The Big One."   Rod David of the trading-advisory service AvidTrader.com, when asked about the recent pattern of abortive early-day selloffs, says, "pullbacks are short, if not also shallow. This stage of the rally is reliant on pre-existing momentum. It's not that more buyers are being attracted, it's that the rally's existing sponsorship isn't being challenged with much selling pressure." That's a positive trend, but one that inevitably ends.     The buyout binge -- now working toward a silly extreme but not there yet -- has driven investors to contemplate once-unthinkable deals. The rail stocks, for instance, are the new trendy targets of catalyst-seeking hedge funds, who contend the rails could vastly increase debt levels, sell their land holdings, buy one another or get bought in leveraged buyouts.   This underscores the degree to which sectors that have always been considered acutely cyclical -- steel and other materials stocks, machinery makers, energy names -- are now seen as perpetual growers thanks to the global development boom. It's at least worth asking whether this song rhymes with the one a decade ago that said tech wasn't cyclical anymore, even if these Old Economy sectors are nowhere near as extended or expensive as late-'90s tech.   When Charles Schwab (SCHW) last week postponed an investor meeting, it prompted reflex speculation that some kind of deal might be afoot. Fox-Pitt Kelton analyst David Trone wrote to clients that he doubted this, yet added that a longshot LBO was "more plausible" on second look, "primarily due to the fact that a massive flood of capital flowing into private-equity firms [is] washing away traditional rules, policies and constraints."   It's as good an expression of the present ethos as any, in which the onetime smart-money buyout pros become -- as the LBO cycle matures -- the greater fools.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Amgen's Got The Goods
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Johanna Bennett   The dip in Amgen shares over drug-safety issues may be overdone. And with multiples bouncing off five-year lows and profits still beating the broader market, Amgen looks cheap at 15.1 times projected profits over the next four quarters.   The stock trades at discounts of 28% to the biotech industry and 6% to the Standard & Poor's 500. And since hitting a record high in September of 2005, its price has fallen 26%. The culprits include new competition, and fears that Amgen is too big while its pipeline is too thin. Management has admitted safety issues may hinder demand for its blockbuster anemia drugs.   Yet Cliff Hoover, co-chief investment officer with Dreman Value Management (which bought Amgen shares last quarter), says: "If investors step back, they see a company of size with good existing drugs and a pipeline," adding it "can grow earnings 10% to 15% annually over the next three years."   With the stock up 16% off a 52-week low on March 29, others appear to agree. Morgan Stanley recently upgraded it to Overweight from Equal Weight. HighMark Capital Management added Amgen to its portfolio last quarter. Still, at "13 or 14 times potential earnings in 2008, [Amgen] is not being rewarded for its potential," says HighMark analyst Robert Kang.   Amgen is the world's largest biotech company by revenues -- $14.3 billion in 2006 -- mostly from drugs to treat chemotherapy's side effects. Anemia-fighting Epogen and Aranesp sales totaled $6.6 billion last year. Infection-fighters Neupogen and Neulasta added $3.9 billion. Sales of rheumatoid-arthritis drug Enbrel exceeded $2.8 billion. And the Food and Drug Administration approved a new colon-cancer drug in September '06. Amgen spent $3.3 billion on research and development last year. It has almost 50 products in development, including potential blockbuster denosumab, to treat osteoporosis.   Unfortunately, Aranesp sales of $4 billion last year may have hit a wall. Several new studies suggest increased risk of heart problems and death for patients using drugs like Aranesp in high doses or outside regulatory guidelines. Medicare health plans have stopped covering off-label use, which has led Amgen to reconsider 2007 revenue projections. Amgen says Arenesp and Epogen are safe when used within FDA guidelines. A study released April 20 bolstered that belief.   Meanwhile, Amgen remains on track to file an application for an important bleeding-disorder treatment.   The company says cost-cutting will get it to the low end of guidance, issued in January, predicting '07 earnings per share of $4.30 to $4.50. "I think we are doing the prudent thing here to deliver value to shareholders," CEO Kevin Sharer said in a first-quarter-results conference call. Amgen reported net profits of 94-cents a share, up 15% versus the same '06 period, on sales of $3.68 billion. Amgen could even beat Wall Street's $4.31 a share consensus estimates for 2007. "They are good at managing earnings expectations, and they have beaten guidance consistently over the last three years," says Montgomery & Co. analyst Shiv Kapoor.   Investors will balk if Amgen lowers financial projections this summer or if denosumab stumbles. But with its promising pipeline and profits, Amgen looks healthy.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:10 ET (04:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Japan's TDK To Build Y50B Ceramic Capacitor Plant - Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--TDK Corp. (6762.TO) plans to build a new ceramic capacitor plant to meet surging demand for the high-performance electronic components used in LCD televisions and mobile-phone handsets, The Nikkei reported in its Sunday edition, citing company sources.   Orders for the devices are increasing as LCD TVs grow in size and more of them are needed for each set, and as the functions of cellular phones and other types of digital equipment grow more advanced.   The Y50 billion facility will be constructed on a lot in an industrial park in Yurihonjo, Akita Prefecture, that the company purchased in March. Building will begin as early as June, with the factory scheduled to go onstream next spring. The plant will boost TDK's output capacity for ceramic capacitors, the mainstay product of the electronic parts maker, by 40% from the level reached in fiscal 2006.   Ceramic capacitors, which can improve power efficiency, are used to reduce power consumption as well as the size of home appliances and communications equipment.  Murata Mfg. Co. (6981.OK), TDK, Taiyo Yuden Co. (6976.TO) and Kyocera Corp. (6971.TO) collectively share nearly 80% of the global market for high-performance capacitors.   Murata and Kyocera each plan to invest several tens of billions of yen to boost production of the components.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 14:04 ET (18:04 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Power Player In The Oil Patch
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Christopher C. Williams   Laid low a few years ago by asbestos claims and other woes, McDermott International is enjoying a new power surge.   The Houston engineering and construction concern, which specializes in providing energy services, has seen profits zoom 400% since 2004, to last year's $342 million, while its stock has more than quadrupled, to 59. After losing almost $1 billion from 2000 through 2003, the 84-year-old firm has been re-energized by a resurgence in exploration and drillingamong oil and gas producers -- driving demand for its offshore platforms and undersea pipelines. Its power-generation unit's emergence from bankruptcy protection last year also is fueling double-digit profit growth.   With a record order backlog of $7.6 billion, McDermott (ticker: MDR) could rally at least into the mid-60s in the next 18 months. Trading for almost 16 times analysts' projected earnings-per-share estimate for '08, the stock is a relatively inexpensive play on the upturn in energy, oil and gas exploration, and the push for cleaner-burning coal.   Analysts think McDermott, with its OxyFuel carbon-dioxide separation technology, could be among the winners in the race to provide a commercial solution to reduce CO2 emissions from power plants. "Both bidding activity and industry fundamentals suggest the company has several years of robust earnings performance ahead of it," says Stephen Gengaro, an analyst with Jefferies & Company.   Analysts project earnings per share will rise 7% this year, to $3.22, and 20% next year, to $3.85. Revenue could grow to $5.8 billion in '08 from the $5.1 billion expected this year. McDermott earned $3.01 a share in '06, on $4.1 billion in revenue. Some analysts expect earnings to grow an average 20% a year for the next three to five years.   Cost-cutting and an integrated portfolio of services give McDermott an industry-leading operating-profit margin of more than 9%. After retiring $250 million of debt in April, the company is virtually debt-free. McDermott had more than $1 billion of cash and equivalents on its balance sheet as of the end of December, some of which management intends to use for acquisitions.   Despite such attributes, McDermott is trading below the average price-to-earnings ratio of 20 times '08 estimates afforded other engineering and construction players such as Fluor (FLR), Foster Wheeler (FWLT) and Shaw Group (SGR). Even more appealing is McDermott's price-to-earnings-growth, or PEG ratio, 0.85.   McDermott's exposure to the volatile offshore-construction market accounts for some of the valuation gap. Also, the stock was hit hard in mid-February when TXU (TXU) suspended contracts with McDermott, after the Texas utility agreed to be bought out by a private-equity group. The loss cuts $1 billion from McDermott's backlog, but analysts expect the company to replace the work with relative ease.   Even with a 22% gain this year, McDermott's stock is trailing most other energy and construction stocks, but analyst John Rogers of D.A. Davidson thinks more project wins and higher earnings will lift the shares 10% in the next 18 months, to 65, or 18 times his '08 estimate of $3.60 a share: "The marine-construction and power-generation segments are in the early stages of significant cyclical recoveries, which should lead to both higher revenue and margins."   Founded in 1923 to supply wooden oil rigs to Texas wildcatters, McDermott has three divisions: offshore oil-and-gas construction, government operations and power-generation systems. It is relying on offshore  construction, which accounts for 39% of sales, to power growth.   With crude fetching $65 a barrel, drillers are rushing to add reserves. Almost 300 oil rigs are operating in international waters, almost double the count from eight years ago, according to oilfield-services company Baker Hughes (BHI). McDermott is going with the flow, so to speak, by building an undersea pipeline in the Caspian Sea and expanding an oil-exploration facility in Qatar. It is bidding on other projects in the Middle East and Asia, as well, and winning some. Marine construction posted a record backlog of $4.1 billion at the end of last year, which the company expects to translate into $2.1 billion of sales this year, up sharply from segment sales of $1.6 billion in 2006.   Brad Handler of Wachovia Capital Markets says that likely project wins in Mexico, and better asset management in the marine-construction business could spur earnings surprises. He thinks McDermott could earn as much as $4.05 a share in 2008. Handler views the stock's gain in recent days -- it hit a record high Friday -- as a possible sign of "growing optimism" among investors that McDermott will beat results for the first quarter when it reports earnings Monday. The Street consensus calls for McDermott to earn $86 million, or 75 cents, for the quarter, on sales of $1.3 billion, up sharply from 48 cents on sales of $645 million in the year-ago period. McDermott officials declined to comment, citing the quiet period before the company's earnings announcement.   McDermott's other businesses, such as government operations, through which it sells nuclear components and has provided site-management services of high-profile jobs -- like the historic Manhattan Project -- will grow at a decidedly slower pace, but are well-positioned to benefit from an expected increase in the building of new coal and nuclear-power plants in the next few years.   The power-generation division, which accounts for 46% of sales, is a leading maker of boilers for coal-fired plants, with a 40% market share. That will rise if the public continues to warm to coal, which is cheaper than natural gas and oil. The Department of Energy estimates 153 new coal plants could come online by 2010.   The power-gen unit has been boosted by the revival of Babcock & Wilcox. McDermott bought B&W in 1978, only to see it crumble under asbestos lawsuits and seek bankruptcy protection in 2000. McDermott excluded B&W from its reported financial statements for six years, before agreeing to settle the claims for more than $900 million in August 2005.   With B&W back in the fold, McDermott has cranked up its effort to commercializing technologies to cut CO2. McDermott recently inked a deal with American Electric Power (AEP) to test its oxy-coal combustion technology on one of AEP's plants, and will complete a pilot demonstration this summer. Commercialization of the technology, which uses pure oxygen for the combustion of coal, isn't expected until at least 2012.   It's a crowded field, but McDermott has made it clear it will be a major player. Citing the company's success with reducing other noxious gases such as fly ash and sodium dioxide, Chairman Bruce Wilkinson said on a conference call in March, "Our engineers often say, 'if you had only told us CO2 was the problem, we would have solved it by now."'   His Texas-size bravado aside, Wilkinson has brought manufacturing and financial discipline, as well as smarter project bidding, to McDermott, since taking over the corner office in 2000.   A whopping 215% return on equity at the end of last year also attests to his management skill. McDermott's singular focus on energy works when demand is hot, but the business can go south quickly, as it did in 2000 when the energy business fizzled. Propelled by high-octane economies such as China and India, the current upturn has a way to go before losing steam, say analysts.   The same can be said for McDermott.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Sen McCain Endures New Political Custom: The Google Interview
Story: By Scott Lindlaw   OF THE ASSOCIATED PRESS   MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. (AP)--For all Sen. John McCain's debate preparation, for all the speeches and chestnuts he has polished in his presidential campaigns, he was not ready for the opening question at the Google Interview.   "How do you determine good ways of sorting 1 million 32-bit integers in two megabytes of RAM?" wondered Google Chief Executive Eric Schmidt. More than 1,000 geeks in the audience roared. A stumped McCain laughed with them.   It was a quirky start to what is becoming a fixture on the presidential campaign - a grilling by the fresh-faced Googlers who are trying to revolutionize the Internet.   In addition to free buffets and an outdoor volleyball court, Google employees now are getting a political perk: A chance to personally question presidential candidates. Company executives, meanwhile, get precious face time to press cherished issues with the politicians who want the White House.   The Google Interview could become the 21st-century equivalent of the candidate's pilgrimage to the General Motors plant. New York Senator and Democratic presidential hopeful Hillary Rodham Clinton was first, in February, followed by McCain on Friday. The company has extended invitations to all the major candidates and expects more campaign appearances in coming weeks.   "I like to think of (seeking) the presidency as a job interview with the American people," Schmidt, who moderates the sessions, told McCain. "And you're also sort of interviewing with Google. It's hard to get a job at Google." The company famously demands college transcripts and high grades; Schmidt's staff whooped at the indirect praise.   "I know I have my work cut out for me," McCain replied.   After apologizing for his mind-bending opening inquiry, Schmidt, a regular Democratic political donor, heaped praise on his GOP interviewee. He asked a series of gentle questions about McCain's Vietnam War combat and POW experiences, a chapter virtually no one in his audience was old enough to recall.   The Googlers listened respectfully, but wanted to talk about the Iraq war, a subject that is weighing down McCain's campaign. McCain has remained steadfastly loyal to President George W. Bush's war policy, including a recent increase in U.S. combat troops and a rejection of timetables for withdrawal.   The candidate delivered a well-worn but impassioned defense of the policy, guaranteeing that "if we have to withdraw on a date-certain, there will be chaos, genocide and other nations in the region will be drawn in."   Schmidt did not challenge this view, but one of his subordinates did.   Why discount the possibility that no one will win the war, the worker asked.   "Any rational observer would say that if the war's lost, then someone won the war," McCain responded. "Al-Qaida will win that war."   Over an hour and two minutes, the questions from the audience were sometimes offbeat, sometimes pointed. One questioner expressed surprise that a Republican would venture into this liberal area 35 miles south of San Francisco; a second said he had campaigned in 2000 for McCain.   Someone else offered him a choice of topics he would like to be questioned on: genocide, campaign finance reform or "the flag." McCain chose the Darfur genocide in Sudan, allowing that the federal government has not done enough, but stopping short of pledging U.S. troops to end it.   One Google worker asked whether McCain could recall his college GPA. The senator did not offer a number, but reminded his listeners that he graduated fifth from the bottom of his class at the U.S. Naval Academy.   For the candidates, the Google Interview is likely to be especially appealing because California has moved its primary up to February 2008, a step the state hopes will force the campaigns to spend more time here.   It is also a chance for the company to tell potential presidents what matters to them.   "It's extremely valuable," said Adam Kovacevich, a Google spokesman. "We think it's important that America's next president understand the importance of the high-tech economy and keeping America competitive."   Among those issues, he said, are "net neutrality," the idea that all Web sites should have equal access to any Internet user, education and immigration changes that would allow more skilled workers into the country.   The candidate visits also include a private tour and a talk with company executives. Kovacevich said lobbying on issues important to the company is not part of those discussions.   With what is expected to be the most expensive presidential campaign in history under way, there is big money at stake, too. Google and other search-engine companies stand to make heaps of it by selling "keyword ads" to the candidates, putting sponsored links to campaign Web sites atop the Google results page.   But most candidates have not bought those terms up, said Erick Obeck, an analyst at SendTec Inc., a search engine marketing ad agency.   As the campaign intensifies, companies like Google could take in millions of dollars each month from the campaigns, he said.   Kovacevich said such salesmanship is not part of the agenda during the private meetings, either.   The salesmanship came from McCain on Friday.   He heaped praise on the Googlers, calling them "the future of this nation."   He pledged that if elected, he would veto wasteful spending and expose "pork-barreling" lawmakers.   "You will know their names - on Google," McCain promised.   On the Net:   McCain's Google appearance: http://tinyurl.com/2u6d54   Clinton's February Google appearance: http://tinyurl.com/355x2d     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 12:26 ET (16:26 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Plugged In: Moto Needs More Than Icahn
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   All eyes Monday will be on the art institute of Chicago, where Motorola is slated to hold its annual shareholder meeting.   This assuredly won't one of your typical stockholder snoozefests. Carl Icahn will be in the house. He's pushing for at least one seat on the board in return for his 3% stake in the beleaguered mobile-phone titan. Last week, he put a full-court press on investors, media members and CEO Ed Zander. If Zander produces signs of a turnaround within a year, "I'll love him," Icahn said in a telephone interview. "If he doesn't, believe me, there's no love."   The clock is ticking for Zander, the former Sun Microsystems No. 2 who is damned if the heavy-hitting activist wins a board seat and damned if he doesn't. Certainly, if Zander can keep Icahn off the board, he buys himself time. But fixing the broken handset business probably will take much more than a year -- at least two years, says Charter Equity Research analyst Ed Snyder, who suggests that private equity vultures are circling.   "It's widely recognized by large shareholders that Zander's days are numbered at Motorola," contends Snyder, who has the equivalent of a Sell on the stock (ticker: MOT). Snyder argues that Zander hasn't put the talent and leadership in place to develop a new phone platform, after pushing out those who were responsible for previous winners like the successful "triplet" flip-phones and the RAZR. "Motorola doesn't have the personnel on the ground to fix things right away," Snyder says.   That's why Icahn may be getting more (or less) than he bargained for. Short-term fixes, such as cutting costs or replacing chip suppliers, won't be enough. Revamping an entire handset line is far more complicated than just whipping up another phone model. In fact, he says, it took Motorola about three years to develop its Nokia-beating flip phones the last time it rebounded from a handset crisis, in 2000-2003.   As a result, Snyder thinks the worst isn't over. The analyst credits the Icahn effect with propping up shares at their current $17-to-$18 level. If the influential activist fails to win a board seat, Snyder believes the stock could drop to $16, which might explain why Icahn is working so hard to salvage his investment. "The stuff I buy is generally unappealing when I buy it," Icahn says. "That's one of the secrets."   Another tenet of his success is picking takeover targets. There's a rumor that Swedish telecom-equipment giant Ericsson (ERIC) has made an unsolicited offer to acquire Motorola at 23 a share. Snyder says that at least two major shareholders say Icahn has been spreading that word. Queried by Barron's, neither Icahn, Motorola or Ericsson would comment on the rumor.   Absent a takeover, the stock goes up and keeps rising only with a turnaround in handsets. Motorola needs a third-generation phone that competes with those that Nokia (NOK), Samsung (005930.Korea) and others already have. (See review of the Nokia N95 at right; it's 3G-capable in Europe, but not in the U.S..) Motorola will have a new 3G handset soon. But, Snyder complains, it won't be on a new platform that would boost margins and functionality.   So Icahn's tried-and-true ability to boost stocks by pressuring management might not provide a long-term lift this time. "Icahn may not have any better idea on how to fix the phone platform than Zander does," Snyder sniffs.   ---   E-mail: mark.veverka@barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) A Body Blow
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Daniel Kaplan   Sports teams and leagues have rarely proven to be good buys, with the economics of professional games frequently ill-suited to investor demands. Just look at World Wrestling Entertainment (ticker: WWE): After coming public in 1999, the shares quickly shot to $25, then plunged to $10 and have been flat this year at about $17.   Now comes the latest player to step into the ring -- International Fight League (IFLI), which came public in November and currently trades around $3. That represents a drop of nearly 65% for most, though not all, of the initial buyers (more on that discrepancy later).   The league showcases what is known as mixed martial arts, an increasingly popular sport that combines aspects of wrestling, boxing and martial arts like karate. The IFL alone attracts some two-million viewers a week on Fox Sports Net, a cable network for regional sports.   The question for investors in this pink-sheet stock, which has a market value of about $160 million, is whether the sport is a passing fad or a replacement for the tattered boxing industry, one that can deliver the young male demographic advertisers covet.   "It has struck a nice chord between the flash of professional wrestling and the sport of boxing," says Bob Thompson, president of Fox National Cable Network, a unit of News Corp. (NWS-A).   Maybe so, but there are some powerful reasons to be wary of IFL, not least that the sport is strikingly bloody and, as a result, legal in only 33 states. A decade ago all states banned it, but some of its more gruesome tactics, like elbows to the head, have been reined in.   Even now, the IFL's New York team can't compete in-state because it is not legal there. "People, including us, are trying to get it approved in New York," said Gareb Shamus, IFL's chief executive.   He won't say when New York might approve the sport -- or when IFL shareholders might expect a profit. The company lost $9.6 million in 2006 on revenues of $2.4 million, according to the most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Most of the cash comes from the arena gate for contests between its 12 teams, though IFL has high hopes for merchandise, digital media and pay-per-view.   Another disturbing disclosure: The company warns it may not have enough insurance if a fighter dies in the ring or is severely injured. Then there's the competition: Fights of the privately held and better-known UFC-Pride are aired on Spike TV.   In all, the stock is at best a gamble. And it is more than a little quirky: Though it came public around $8.50, the company orchestrated a small private stock sale at under $2 a share shortly afterwards (and all the shares now trade at the same price). Those who bought the stock at the higher price were mainly fans, while the bargain shares went to savvier investors, says Joe Besecker, founder of Emerald Asset Management. That firm does not own IFL stock, though Besecker himself owns some.   Shamus wouldn't comment on the discrepancy between the public and private offering price, other than to say the company did what was needed to raise money. It may need to do a lot more to win shareholder loyalty.   ---   Daniel Kaplan is a sports-business writer based in New York.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) A Clean Bill Of Health
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jonathan R. Laing   Go figure. two weeks ago, Wellpoint, the nation's biggest health insurer in terms of members, announced a 16% jump in first-quarter earnings per share and boosted its full-year 2007 earnings guidance by a penny, to $5.54 a share -- up more than 15% from the year-ago number. And yet the stock got toasted, falling some 4% to around 79, before recovering to just 81.43.   One culprit was concern over a rise in the company's so-called benefit expense ratio (the amount it pays out to doctors, hospitals and the like as a percentage of its premium revenues) to 83.1%, from 81.3% in last year's first quarter. Could it be, investors wondered, that WellPoint, the long-regarded Steady Eddy of health insurance underwriting, had allowed itself to be blindsided by an unanticipated surge in medical-cost inflation and set its premium levels too low?   At the same time, Wall Street seemed to be picking up on the less-than-subliminal message from contenders for the Democratic nomination for president, with their nostrums to rein in health-care costs and improve quality of care -- while at the same time extending health insurance to all, including America's 47 million uninsured.   Private, for-profit health insurers like WellPoint are largely seen as greedy middlemen driving up administrative costs and often denying needed care in order enrich their shareholders at the expense of the country's citizenry. Investors worry that any evolution to a single-payer health system -- largely funded by taxpayers rather than corporations -- could disintermediate insurers like WellPoint. The company currently covers some 35 million Americans through its ownership of Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans in 14 states, including California, New York, Ohio, Indiana and Connecticut   If nothing else, however, the recent selloff has made WellPoint even more attractive to analysts like Prudential's David Shove. He thinks the stock (ticker: WLP) could hit 100 within 12 months, up 23% from current levels. That is quite plausible, and it would continue a trajectory that Barron's anticipated two years ago, when the shares were at 67 ("WellPoint's Advantage," July 25, 2005).   Shove is optimistic on several scores. First, he contends that the "Blues" boast tremendous brand loyalty in the regions they operate in. Moreover, WellPoint serves a diversity of markets -- from Fortune 500 companies (most of whom pay their own claims but rely on private insurers to administer their programs) to smaller corporate and group plans to individual policyholders, including Medicare and Medicaid patients. Finally, the stock is cheap, selling at just 12.7 times the consensus 2008 earnings forecast of $6.39 a share.   WellPoint can continue to deliver annual earnings growth of 15% or more, even in a slower-growth economy, says R. Hutchings "Hutch" Vernon of Alex Brown Investment Management. WellPoint's revenues, he figures, should continue to grow by 8% or so annually, by virtue of the secular rise in medical costs, which in turns reflects advances in technology and treatment regimens and the aging of the affluent Baby Boomer generation. Meantime, WellPoint's sheer scale permits it to contain the growth in its administrative costs, allowing the company's margins to increase on an ever-growing revenue base.   "WellPoint is in the enviable position of running a toll booth in an area where traffic and rates go up each year," says Vernon. "Also, we like the fact that health insurance is a 'short-tail' business in which mistakes in setting premium rates can be rectified within a year or less if claims suddenly surge. After health insurers ran into trouble pricing their products in the '90s, companies like WellPoint really learned underwriting discipline. Today, health insurance isn't subject to the vicious cycles like, say, the property casualty insurance industry."   At the same time, WellPoint is throwing off prodigious amounts of cash flow and using it to bolster its financial results via heavy stock buybacks. For the 12 months ended March 31, the company's fully diluted share count shrank by nearly 7%. It currently is in the midst of a $3 billion stock repurchase program.   This year alone, WellPoint expects to generate operating cash flow of $4.4 billion. Since required capital spending will only amount to around $325 million, the company will have plenty of cash left over for buybacks or even judicious, fill-in acquisitions, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer David Colby told Barron's in a phone interview. "We could easily retire all our stock outstanding in eight years or so as a result of our cash generation, though, of course, we won't do that," he observes.   The recent slide in WellPoint's stock seems overdone for yet other reasons. The jump in the medical-claims ratio in the first quarter looks to be mostly the result of delayed hikes in Medicaid (a state-federal insurance program primarily for low-income Americans) reimbursements to WellPoint in two states that will soon be rectified.   Largely ignored was the fact that the company was able to maintain its profit margins by driving down its administrative-expense ratio from 15.9% of premium revenues in the year-ago quarter to 14.4% by increasing efficiencies in its back-office procedures. In other words, to the aggregator of insured lives go the spoils.   "Health insurance is one business in which size really does confer nothing but economies of scale," Colby says. "We can leverage our scale to negotiate better deals with hospitals, doctors, pharmaceutical companies, outpatient clinics and other providers, while also lowering claims-processing costs and the like by investing in better information technology. This is a business that runs on common systems and common applications."   Efficient, major private insurers like WellPoint and UnitedHealth Group (ticker: UNH) are already deeply entrenched in key government-funded programs such as Medicare and Medicaid, thereby making it unlikely that the industry will ever be entirely dislodged from the U.S. health insurance system by any evolution toward a single-payer, nationalized health care.   For example, WellPoint superintends some two million Medicaid program beneficiaries, contracting the company's services to various state Medicaid agencies. The company has been able to make a satisfactory profit on this business, even though WellPoint receives reimbursements of only 95% of the rates that the state entities pay to various hospitals and doctors for services provided directly to Medicaid recipients. Still, the company has enjoyed success in the program as a result of innovative disease-management techniques, reliance on preventative care and volume discounts with the hospitals and doctors in its various networks.   WellPoint also processes Medicare claims in 26 states and five U.S. territories on behalf of 22.5 million seniors.   In no federal health-insurance program has the private insurance industry played a bigger part than in the Part D drug benefit added on to Medicare in 2003. Despite dire predictions from critics of free-market health insurance, the Bush Administration's decision to rely on private insurers rather than some federal bureaucracy to negotiate drug prices, set premium rates and administer the program has proven a signal success. Competition from a score of companies has driven down premium rates far below the most optimistic projections while affording seniors a profusion of different policy packages.   Even the most ardent advocates of single-payer national health are now reluctant to tamper with the Part D program because it is wildly popular among seniors, with an 80% satisfaction rating. And seniors vote their pocketbooks. WellPoint is currently the third-largest Part D insurer, behind UnitedHealth Group and Humana (HUM), covering some 1.6 million seniors.   Democrats may be more successful in choking off the so-called Medicare Advantage program that permits private insurers to offer their own Medicare coverage featuring lower deductibles and co-pays in return for more limited networks.   Despite the fact that nearly 20% of all Medicare beneficiaries have opted for the program, including many minority seniors, opponents seize on the fact that the federal government pays slightly higher reimbursements to Medicare Advantage insurers than it does for the same services provided by hospitals and doctors directly. In any case, any gutting of the program shouldn't affect WellPoint much, since it covers only 350,000 Medicare Advantage insureds.   Leonard Schaeffer, chairman of WellPoint until his departure in 2005, predicts that U.S. health insurance system will remain a mix of private and government-run programs in the years ahead. A nationalized, single-payer system would be difficult to implement, for one thing. The bureaucracy and procedures alone would be dauntingly complex, especially when many of the systems are already in place in the private sector. "If there were chaos for the first three years or so going to a national program and costs were to balloon, there would be political hell to pay," he observes. "In any health-insurance program, the devil is always in the details."   Schaeffer over the years has achieved something of a guru status on health-care issues because of his wide experience. He ran the federal Medicare program during the later years of the Carter Administration. In 1986, he took over Blue Cross of California, when the association was for all intents and purposes bankrupt.   Within a decade, he transformed the company into a for-profit, and hit the acquisition trail to gain a national presence. His biggest deal was a reverse merger with another Blue Cross roll-up, Anthem, in 2004. Since Anthem became the successor concern, the corporate headquarters were moved from California to Anthem's home in Indianapolis, although Anthem ultimately adopted the WellPoint name.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: =WSJ: Buffett Reiterates Caution On Derivatives
Story: By Karen Richardson     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     OMAHA, Neb. (Dow Jones)--Billionaire Warren Buffett repeated his warning that the growth of derivatives and excessive borrowing by traders, investors and corporations will eventually lead to significant dislocation in the financial markets.   In fielding a question about derivatives, which he once referred to as "financial weapons of mass destruction," Buffett told some 27,000 shareholders at the annual meeting Saturday of his Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (BRKA) holding company in Omaha that he expects derivatives and borrowing, or leverage, would inevitably end in huge losses for many financial participants.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   "The introduction of derivatives has totally made any regulation of margin requirements a joke," said Buffett, referring to the U.S. government's rules limiting the amount of borrowed money an investor can apply to each trade. "I believe we may not know where exactly the danger begins and at what point it becomes a super danger. We don't know when it will end precisely, but...at some point some very unpleasant things will happen in markets."   Buffett has expressed similar bearish sentiments about derivatives in previous meetings and in his widely read annual letters to shareholders. He had first-hand experience with the difficulties of derivatives after Berkshire acquired General Re, the reinsurance company, in the late 1990s, and spent several years unwinding its derivatives portfolio at a loss to reduce the subsidiary's exposure to risk. He noted, however, that Berkshire currently has several dozen derivatives positions - such as futures and options contracts on stock indexes and foreign currencies - and added that "derivatives aren't evil."   Charlie Munger, Berkshire's 83-year-old vice-chairman and Buffett's droll sidekick during the six-hour annual meeting, said that the accounting of derivatives contributed to the risks they pose to the financial markets. Derivative accounting doesn't adequately reflect the underlying risk to a company's balance sheet, he said.   "The accounting being deficient enormously contributes to the risk," said Munger, lamenting that executives and shareholders were getting paid on "profits that don't exist."   Buffett noted that existing accounting conventions allow parties involved in derivative transactions to value the same contract differently, leading to inadequate or incomplete picture of the contract's risk. "I will guarantee you, if you add up the marks on both side, they don't add up to zero," Buffett said, referring to the accounting of a single derivative contract.   Exacerbating the problem of derivatives and leverage is the short-term trading mentality and high turnover in the stock and bond markets, Buffett and Munger added. "There is an electronic herd of people around the world managing an amazing amount of money" who make decisions based on minute-by-minute stimuli, said Buffett, adding, "I think it's a fool's game."     -By Karen Richardson, The Wall Street Journal; Karen.Richardson@wsj.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 13:21 ET (17:21 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: =WSJ: Buffett: Newspaper Industry Woes Stem From Tech Changes
Story: By Karen Richardson     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     OMAHA, Neb. (Dow Jones)--Billionaire Warren Buffett Saturday blamed the decline of sales and circulation in the newspaper industry to technological and cultural changes, and not on the dual-class shareholder structure of some major media companies.   "The truth is, the world has changed in a significant way,"  Buffett told shareholders at the Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (BRKA) annual shareholder meeting in Omaha. He said early titans of the newspaper industry couldn't have changed the fundamental realities of the Internet age.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   "I don't know that Joseph Pulitzer or William Randolph Hearst or E.W. Scripps could do much about that," he said.   Buffett is a director at the Washington Post Co. (WPO), which has a dual-class share structure similar to the New York Times Co. (NYT) and Dow Jones & Co. (DJ).   Dow Jones publishes this and other newswires, as well as The Wall Street Journal and its international and online editions.   The dual-class structure concentrates voting power in one class of shares in those cases, with a majority of the voting shares held by families that have controlled the companies for decades.   Recently, the structure has come under pressure from shareholders of the New York Times. Last week, an offer from Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. (NWS) to buy Dow Jones threw a spotlight on the structure at that company.   "I don't blame the dual-class structure for anyone's losses at the New York Times," said Buffett, referring to the company's share price, which is down sharply over the past five years.     -By Karen Richardson, The Wall Street Journal; karen.richardson@wsj.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 16:38 ET (20:38 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
