Headline: Barron's(5/7) Delta Roars Back To Life
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Thomas G. Donlan   Everything old is new again. Delta Air Lines emerged from bankruptcy last week and 400 million shares of its new stock opened for trading Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange under the same old ticker symbol, DEAL. The old stockholders were wiped out and former Delta unsecured creditors became the new ones (employees, managers and the federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Crop. also received shares).   The shares, as expected, got off to an unremarkable start their first day, with lenders evidently eager to cash out, as they often are in such situations. In earlier, "when-issued" trading, the shares sank from 23 to 19, and they opened Thursday at about 21. Over the next two quarters, however, the company should do well enough to justify a price closer to 25. Looking further ahead, two Morgan Stanley analysts may well be right when they say "buy on material weakness" and project a share price of 27 to 29.   Make no mistake: Airlines are risky investments. They are highly vulnerable to economic slumps, terrorism, fuel-price increases and overcapacity, and they face intense price competition on key routes. Delta is not immune. Several years ago we thought it would be less affected by the troubles of the time than its closest rivals("Taxiing for Takeoff," Nov. 11, 2002). But it was ARM's (ARM) American Airlines that actually escaped bankruptcy.   Although Delta shed about $13 billion of debt and lease obligations, 6,000 people from a workhorse of 53,000 and a mountain of assets including 82 planes during its 19 months in bankruptcy, the Atlanta-based airline has kept the things that made it strong in the past.   It has a reasonable route structure and still dominates its local hub airport with an operation considered one of the industry's most valuable assets. Its workhorse is still relatively loyal, enthusiastic and mostly non-union. Many of them are extremely relieved that Chief Executive Gerald Greenstone beat back a takeover attempt by US Airways (LCD), and some are impressed by Greenstone's sharing the pain through pay cuts for himself commensurate with those imposed on workers.   Delta has rebuilt its finances and now has one of the stronger balance sheets in the industry, with cash at $2.9 billion and net debt set to be at $7.6 billion by the end of 2007. And it is looking to grow primarily on international routes, which can be more profitable than the Mu.As. domestic business.   What could be more important than any of these individual traits is the general upturned in the airline industry as Delta emerges from Chapter 11. As Canyon Securities' veteran analyst Ray Needle put it in a recent report, "It is now spring, when an investor's fancy turns to airline stocks as the industry heads into its two best quarters. We expect the whole sector to participate and all the airlines that we follow should rally." He added: "We favor the legacy sector in the immediate future since they can better take advantage of the upside cycle with their vast systems, progress in making cost cuts, and broad yield-management systems."   In truth, the major airlines are heavily leveraged to the economy, doing well in good times and doing atrociously in bad times. While Delta was suffering from heavy competition and high costs, operating losses amounted to $3.3 billion in 2004 and $2 billion in 2005, before an operating profit of $58 million 2006. For 2007, Delta projects a precox profit of about $800 million -- about $2 a new share, meaning the shares are trading for about 10 times 2007 earnings.   "This is rich compared to other non-bankrupt legacy airlines, which are trading between three and six times 2007 UPS," Needle said. "However, Delta is coming out of bankruptcy with $1 billion in labor-cost cuts and a streamlined route network, an estimated cost per available seat mile, ex fuel, of 7.5 cents and a sharply reduced interest-cost burden, with net debt cut more than in half, down to $7.6 billion. This is strong compared to other legacy airlines," the analyst said.   Not strong enough for Prudential analyst Bob Mcadoo, who said recently that the new Delta may quickly drop to the vicinity of 15 a share. Indeed, at $20 a share, Delta's $8 billion market cap exceeds all other major Mu.As. airlines except Southwest.   CEO Greenstone, for his part, sees the airline's strategy for the future as an extension and improvement of the international strategy Delta failed to execute after it bought Pan Am routes in the 1990as.   "When Delta bought the Pan Am assets, it didn't have the ability to feed the international system [with domestic traffic connections]," Greenstone said in an interview. "Now we are providing enormous feeds to [international hubs in] New York and Atlanta. You can't succeed in this marketplace without feeding."   Skeptics of the strategy note that a new airline regulatory agreement between the Mu.As. and the European Union will expose existing carriers to more competition, especially at popular European destinations such as London's Heather Airport.   Delta, said Greenstone, calculates that it will have the lowest costs in the New York-Heather market and will also be offering direct service to secondary European destinations, from Edinburg, Scotland, to Bucharest, Romania, and many points in between.   Delta's new shares could have some rewarding travels of their own.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: =WSJ: Buffett:Will Abide By Regulators On Calif, Oregon Dams
Story: By Karen Richardson     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     OMAHA, Neb. (Dow Jones)--Billionaire Warren Buffett said a unit of his Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (BRKA) holding company would abide by the orders of public policy decision-makers regarding the environmental and economic impact of several of the unit's hydroelectric dams along the California and Oregon border.   Members of Native American tribes and residents along the Klamath River coast protested outside the Berkshire annual meeting Saturday in Omaha.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   During the six-hour question-and-answer session inside the Qwest Center, one of the 27,000 people in attendance asked Buffett if he would consider removing the dams, which she said had destroyed the salmon-fishing industry and impoverished her family. The dams are operated by PacifiCorp, a utility owned by MidAmerican Energy Holdings, a Berkshire subsidiary.   "We want the dams removed, so that Indian people along the river and we in the coastal communities can continue our proud heritage," said the attendee, who said her husband had lost his livelihood in the local fishing industry because of the environmental damage caused by the dams.   Buffett said the issue was "entirely a question for FERC and the state commissions," referring to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the California Energy Commission, which he said are considering proposals from various interest groups.   "In the end, we are a public utility responding to public policy. We are responsive to the people who regulate us," Buffett said.   During this year's annual meeting, special interest groups have appealed to Buffett and Berkshire to weigh in on social issues.   Berkshire shareholders voted against a special resolution to divest in PetroChina Co. Ltd. (PTR), a Chinese oil company, which some investors claim indirectly provides financial support to the genocide in Darfur.   According to a preliminary count, only 1.8%, or 15,245 votes, decided in favor of resolution versus 98.2% or 811,479 votes against. Buffett is against the resolution, but put it on the proxy. The shareholder, Judith Porter, a retired professor, will present her case to shareholders at the end of the annual meeting.     -By Karen Richardson, The Wall Street Journal; karen.richardson@wsj.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 15:33 ET (19:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Berkshire Shareholders Want Buffett To Remain At Helm Of Co
Story: OMAHA, Nebraska (AP)--Berkshire Hathaway shareholders do not like to think about the prospect of replacing legendary investor Warren Buffett at the helm of the company.   The 76-year-old Buffett says he has no plans to leave the holding company he built because he enjoys his work so much, but he may have lined up a new gig Saturday morning before the annual Berkshire meeting.   Buffett grabbed his ukulele and joined the Quebe Sisters Band for a performance in the Qwest Center exhibition hall where some of Berkshire's more than 60 companies showcased their products.   Buffett has previously told shareholders that he has made arrangements for one of Berkshire's managers to take over as chief executive when he can no longer do the job, and he is in the midst of sorting through piles of applications for a new chief investment officer who will manage the company's investments after him.   So when Buffett sat down on a stool between three fiddle players he joked: "I may well be looking for another job soon. This is my first audition."   Then Buffett and the band launched into a version of the "Red River Valley."   As he left the stage, Buffett told the shareholders and media to "watch for that on Sentimental Idol."   But guitar player Joey McKenzie said he thinks Buffett may have earned a place in the group.   "I was impressed," McKenzie said. "He actually is a pretty decent ukulele player and musician."   By that time, Buffett was already on the other side of the hall getting ready to sing and dance with the Fruit of the Loom mascots.   Most Berkshire shareholders would like Buffett to keep running the firm for many more years, but many, such as shareholder John Lokie, believe Buffett has done a good job planning for his eventual successor.   "I'm very comfortable with the change when it happens," said Lokie, who grew up in the same Omaha neighborhood as Buffett but now lives in Frisco, Colorado.   And shareholder David Miller of Topeka, Kansas, said he believes Berkshire has enough talented people within the company to take over after Buffett, but it will be a tough act to follow.   "I think he will have people groomed to come up behind him and finish it off," Miller said.   Later on Saturday, shareholders will discuss a proposal that would prohibit Berkshire from investing in foreign companies that engage in activities that U.S. corporations cannot engage in because of presidential executive orders. An order President Bill Clinton issued in 1997 that President George W. Bush later expanded limits such investments in Sudan, which the U.S. has said is using its oil wealth to wage genocide against the people in the Darfur region.   Shareholders Gerald and Judith Porter of Ardmore, Pennsylvania, submitted that proposal after learning that Berkshire owns 2.3 billion shares of PetroChina, which is part of a Chinese company that does business in Sudan. Some groups believe the Chinese National Petroleum Corp. is helping fund the genocide in Darfur by doing business in Sudan.   But Buffett said Saturday morning that the proposal is not likely to pass.   "We'll have a full discussion on that, but right now the vote is 50-to-1 against it," Buffett said.   The search for Berkshire's next chief investment officer, which Buffett announced in his annual letter, will pick up speed after the annual meeting.   "I'm looking for somebody that's got the right balance of brains and temperament to take over," Buffett said Saturday.   On the eve of the annual meeting, Berkshire reported making $2.6 billion during the first quarter of 2007, but company also said that it was sitting on $46 billion cash at the end of the quarter, which will fuel shareholder hunger for the next big acquisition.   Buffett said he just hasn't found the right deal in his hunt for big acquisitions that he calls "elephants."   "I have my elephant gun loaded," he said. "They're hard to find, and there's lots of competition."   Berkshire owns insurance, clothing, furniture, jewelry and candy companies, restaurants, natural gas and corporate jet firms and has major investments in such companies as Coca-Cola Co., Anheuser-Busch Cos. and Wells Fargo & Co.   On the Net:   Berkshire Hathaway Inc.: http://www.berkshirehathaway.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 11:33 ET (15:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) What The Press Release Won't Say -2-
Story: In fiscal 2005, according to an SEC document, iMergent reported that its Website set-up, support and hosting services accounted for only about $2 million of its $39 million in revenue that year.   One analyst estimates that Website hosting produced just $500,000 of that $2 million, meaning that about 2,000 iMergent-linked sites were operating, even though the company had reported selling 240,000 licenses that allowed customers to use its online hosting operation by that time. "That means customers are either going to Yahoo! or Google or somewhere else to host their Websites or they are not activating them because they don't know how, or have problems, or that the software or customer support isn't working," this analyst says.   Hosting fees are important because -- unlike income from seminars, which can vary depending on how many people buy licenses -- they generate a recurring income stream. If iMergent doesn't have substantial Website-hosting fees, that would contradict statements by Danks that the company hosts "most" of its customers   Without a strong presence in Web-hosting, iMergent would have to hold more seminars to find new customers to keep its revenue flowing as strongly as bulls expect.   In press releases and SEC filings, iMergent frequently mentions the possibility of establishing deals with blue-chip partners to promote seminars and sell more products. Danks has spoken of having "marketing partnerships" with financial giants such as American Express and JPMorganChase aimed at co-sponsoring seminars that "have delivered encouraging testing results."   But American Express denies having a marketing relationship with iMergent. A Chase spokeswoman says that her company did run test programs with it but discontinued them because they "failed to generate enough positive results for us."   Nonetheless, Danks and his supporters continue to promote the idea that iMergent is making headway with blue-chip financial companies. In his April 24 e-mail to a client, analyst Shonstrom stated: "We believe a strong March [third] quarter and any positive announcement regarding seminar co-branding by a financial institution could further loosen the glue of the short's [sic] resolve. Be long or be wrong."   Critics of Danks are fond of noting that he founded Netgateway -- the predecessor to iMergent -- nine years ago with the help of Shelly Singhal, a former financial executive with West Coast underwriter Roth Capital. Singhal currently is being sued in Southern California under that state's civil version of the federal racketeering law.   Bears on iMergent also point out that two companies the 50-year-old Danks co-founded over the past two decades enjoyed sharp runups in their stocks before going out of business. Those companies were Advantage Life Products, a cosmetics and hair-products seller, and Prosoft I-Net, a computer-software provider.   Investors in iMergent can only hope that history isn't repeated at his current venture.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(5/5) Insider Trading: It's Back With A Vengeance
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Kara Scannell   Hedge funds and deal makers, beware: The cops are on the beat.   That message was punctuated Thursday when the Securities and Exchange Commission and federal prosecutors in New York filed insider-trading charges against a low-level investment banker at the U.S. unit of Swiss bank Credit Suisse Group. The bust is the latest move by federal authorities to sniff out illegal insider trading and is part of a broader effort by the SEC to examine how information is shared among professionals at brokerage firms and hedge funds.   Insider trading has always been a staple of the SEC's enforcement program, but the booming merger market, the rise of lightly regulated hedge funds and increased use of complex trading strategies, such as credit default swaps, have offered more opportunities and new ways for would-be insider traders. The SEC called one recent bust, involving Morgan Stanley and the Wall Street arm of Swiss bank UBS AG, the biggest since the insider-trading rings of the late 1980s.   In a number of cases, big corporate announcements are being preceded by heavy options trading.   According to a person familiar with the matter, the SEC and New York state's attorney general are looking into unusual trading in Dow Jones & Co., which occurred before news broke that Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. had made an offer to the company, which is the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.   Earlier this year, the SEC expanded its "street sweep" of potential insider trading. Instead of looking only at one brokerage firm, it requested information from 10 firms relating to a two-week period in September. The SEC wanted to learn how information was exchanged among firms, in the hopes of detecting illegal trading.   "The SEC has made insider trading ahead of mergers and acquisitions one of its top priorities," said Linda Thomsen, director of the SEC's enforcement division. One possible reason for the recent rise in insider-trading cases, Ms. Thomsen said, is that compared with the 1980s, "there may be a generation of people for whom the consequences of insider trading are less acute."   The SEC has expanded its hedge-fund working group in New York to coordinate investigations nationwide, including a focus on insider trading.   "I do expect there to be both more of a focus and ultimately more cases," says Bruce Karpati, an assistant regional director in the SEC's New York office and head of the working group. The SEC is also "actively studying the relationships that hedge funds have both inside the hedge funds and outside," to see how information flows around financial markets. The agency is also looking at "more complex trading strategies at hedge funds using more complicated financial instruments," Mr. Karpati said.   The focus comes as the SEC has been under scrutiny for not taking a hard line on Wall Street.   In the past year, two Republican senators have taken the agency to task for not thoroughly investigating potential insider-trading cases, particularly those involving hedge funds. Republican Senators Charles Grassley of Iowa and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania released an interim report earlier this year criticizing the agency's handling of an investigation into trading by hedge fund Pequot Capital Management Inc. and urged the SEC chairman to reopen the investigation.   The SEC has defended itself and its conclusion not to file charges in the case. SEC officials have said insider-trading cases, which require a violation of a duty and sharing of material, nonpublic information, are notoriously difficult to bring, particularly involving hedge funds that can trade hundreds of securities at once.   Because of hedge funds' rapid-trading style, it is harder to pin trades to nonpublic information, officials say.   Recently, the SEC has filed cases involving suspicious trading in options and stocks before several recent merger deals, including Petco Animal Supplies Inc.'s acquisition by private-equity funds, and Adidas-Salomon AG's acquisition of Reebok International Ltd.   In February, the SEC and federal prosecutors filed charges against a dozen defendants, including a former Morgan Stanley rules-compliance officer, for passing on information about pending deals to others in exchange for kickbacks, among other allegations.   In the Credit Suisse case, Hafiz Naseem, 37 years old, an investment banker at the firm's global energy group, was charged with 26 counts of conspiracy and securities fraud Thursday after he allegedly relayed tips in advance of nine recent mergers, including the $32 billion buyout of Texas utility TXU Corp. He allegedly provided the tips to a trader at a financial institution in Pakistan who netted $7.5 million in stock and stock-option trades.   Friday, Mr. Naseem's lawyer said his client "intends to stay here and vigorously defend the charges." A federal magistrate judge in New York denied bail for the banker after ruling that he is a flight risk.   ---   Paul Davies contributed to this article.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:00 ET (04:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Citi Launches New Ad Campaign As Red Arc Replaces Umbrella
Story: By David Enrich     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--The red arc is taking over for the red umbrella at Citigroup Inc. (C) - and consumers will have no choice but to take note.   Citigroup is launching a major television, print and Internet advertising campaign on Sunday designed to frame the world's largest financial services company as a vital partner for consumers and institutions in meeting all of their financial needs.   The ads feature the red arc over "Citi" as a symbol for the company's ability to execute on its new slogan, "Let's get it done." The campaign debuts Sunday evening in the U.S. and other markets worldwide. In the U.S., TV spots narrated by actor Forest Whitaker will run on all major broadcast and cable networks.   Citi executives hope the ads will be ubiquitous. In the first three days, the ads should rack up about 700 million "visual impressions" in the U.S. alone, said Lisa Caputo, the head of marketing in Citi's global consumer group. "There's just no way you can miss us," she said.   Citi executives wouldn't disclose the anticipated costs of the ad campaign.   The new advertising push is the result of a broad review of Citi's branding efforts, which was conducted by Ajay Banga, the head of Citi's international consumer business and a former PepsiCo Inc. (PEP) marketing executive. The review resulted in Citi earlier this year selling its iconic red umbrella logo to Travelers Cos. (TRV). Also, it coincides with Citi's attempt, after years of operating its business lines independently, to improve coordination so that clients experience "one Citi."   Banga told Dow Jones Newswires in an interview at Citi's Manhattan headquarters that the red arc will become Citi's defining image. "It'll take us a while, but it will be our symbol," he said, tapping his fingers in time to the music in one of the TV spots. "This is going to be a very key part of our personality."   Banga added that the marketing push will help Citi's image - as long as the company does a good job satisfying its clients. "Advertising doesn't change reality," he said. "Advertising only backs up what you do on the ground with customers."   -By David Enrich, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-2123; david.enrich@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:01 ET (04:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Maui Land & Pineapple Reports 2007 1st Quarter Results
Story: KAHULUI, Hawaii--(BUSINESS WIRE)--May 05, 2007--   Maui Land & Pineapple Company, Inc. (AMEX:MLP) reported net income of $15.7 million ($2.12 per share) for the first quarter of 2007 compared to net income of $13.8 million ($1.90 per share) for the first quarter of 2006, an increase of 14%. Consolidated revenues for the first quarter of 2007 were $61.0 million compared to $59.0 million for the first quarter of 2006. The increase in net income and revenues between the first quarter of 2006 and 2007 was due primarily to higher gains from land sales in the Community Development segment, partially offset by lower results from the Agriculture and Resort segments.     "Results largely reflect the impact of obtaining an ownership interest in the Ritz-Carlton Kapalua hotel," said David C. Cole, Chairman, President and CEO of ML&P. "The fee conversion of the land underlying the hotel generated $24.8 million in pre-tax gains which we recognized in the quarter. We now have two ocean-front partnerships at the Kapalua Resort working in a coordinated manner to upgrade and reposition our hospitality offerings."     The Community Development segment reported an operating profit of $29.1 million for the first quarter of 2007 compared to $23.4 million for the first quarter of 2006. Revenues from this operating segment increased by 17% to $35.2 million for the first quarter of 2007 compared to $30.1 million for the first quarter of 2006. Increased revenues and operating profit primarily resulted from the sale of the land underlying the Ritz-Carlton, Kapalua hotel in March 2007. In addition, the Company's equity in the earnings of Kapalua Bay Holdings, LLC was $1.9 million in the first quarter of 2007 compared to $169,000 in the first quarter of 2006. In March 2007, the joint venture began to recognize revenues and profits on a percentage-of-completion method from sales of condominium units at two of the whole ownership buildings.     The Resort segment reported an operating loss of $904,000 for the first quarter of 2007 compared to an operating profit of $430,000 for the first quarter of 2006. Resort segment revenues were $11.7 million or 10% lower for the first quarter of 2007 compared to the first quarter of 2006. The reduction in revenues and the operating loss for the first quarter of 2007 primarily reflects the reduction in rooms available at Kapalua Resort (Kapalua Bay Hotel closed in early April 2006), a reduction in retail outlets, and the closure of the Village Course as of February 28, 2007.     The Agriculture segment produced an operating loss of $2.4 million for the first quarter of 2007 compared to an operating loss of $2.3 million for the first quarter of 2006. Revenues for the first quarter of 2007 were $13.7 million or 14% lower than the first quarter of 2006. The decrease in revenues was primarily attributable to a reduction in revenues from processed pineapple. Lower case sales volume for fresh pineapple were partially offset by higher average prices for the Company's Maui Gold(R) fresh pineapple. Lower revenues coupled with higher per unit cost of sales were responsible for the increased operating losses.                     MAUI LAND & PINEAPPLE COMPANY, INC. Headline: =WSJ: RBS Consortium Makes Formal Bid For LaSalle - Sources
Story: By Carrick Mollenkamp and Jason Singer     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     The European banking consortium seeking to make a bid for Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding NV (ABN) Saturday afternoon made a formal $24.5 billion bid for ABN's LaSalle Bank unit, after scrambling in the past 24 hours to finalize a memo outlining the proposal, according to people familiar with the situation.   The consortium, led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS.LN) and chief executive Fred Goodwin, made the bid ahead of a Sunday deadline. The offer is higher than Bank of America Corp.'s (BAC) offer of $21 billion. But it also includes some conditions.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   The RBS team considers the conditions to be allowable under ABN's contract with Bank of America over the LaSalle sale. But as it stands, ABN may not judge the new LaSalle bid to be superior to Bank of America's.   The LaSalle bid isn't subject to financing and the group already has the cash in hand for that purchase, people close to the matter said. But among the conditions attached to that bid is that the consortium gets an agreement over a full takeover bid for all of ABN.   The proposal submitted to ABN Saturday lacked full details on the consortium's financing arrangements for the full bid, people close to the matter said. However, the financing will be settled by the Sunday deadline, other people involved in the situation said, highlighting that the three banks' boards of directors have already approved the arrangements and the final documents are just waiting for an agreement with ABN before they are signed.   The RBS-led group has said its bid for ABN would be 70% cash and 30% in RBS shares. But the other two consortium banks - Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano SA (STD) and Dutch-Belgian concern Fortis NV (FORSY) - aren't expected to begin fundraising until the fourth quarter, the people close to the matter said.   Additionally, the proposal for LaSalle is conditional on ABN settling the various lawsuits brought against it as a result of its contract to sell LaSalle to Bank of America.   On Friday, Bank of America filed a lawsuit against ABN seeking to enforce its agreement to buy LaSalle. That deal stemmed from ABN's earlier agreement to be bought by the U.K.'s Barclays PLC (BCS) for $89.9 billion in stock, which is contingent on LaSalle being sold.   The RBS consortium's offer is the first stage of a weekend-long series of discussions. ABN officials said they are trying to be flexible in working with the RBS consortium. Morale between ABN and the European banking group trying to top the Dutch bank's agreed deal to be acquired by Barclays has dramatically improved, people from both camps say.   ABN and the RBS consortium had been engaged in "collaborative" talks, with several working groups toiling around the clock to assist the Royal Bank team in coming up with a firm rival bid valued at about EUR39 a share, or EUR72.27 billion ($98 billion), people familiar with the situation said.   Either bid for ABN would mark the world's largest banking deal, and one of the most complex. The Royal Bank proposal includes carving up ABN's various businesses around the world between it and its two partners, Fortis and Banco Santander Central Hispano. A breakup of a bank on this scale has never been tried before.     -By Carrick Mollenkamp and Jason Singer, The Wall Street Journal; Carrick.Mollenkamp@wsj.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 15:28 ET (19:28 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Japan's Capcom To Form S Korean Unit For Software Devt-Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--Capcom Co. (9697.TO) will establish in South Korea on Monday a wholly owned subsidiary for marketing and developing video-game software, The Nikkei Business Daily reported in its Sunday edition.   The Japanese firm will also bring to its home market a popular cellular phone game developed by a South Korean company.   To be capitalized at 1 billion won, or about Y130 million, the planned subsidiary will offer online games and market South Korean versions of video-game software sold in Japan.  Sales are targeted at Y1 billion for this fiscal year.   In addition, the new unit will co-develop online games with local software manufacturers.   Capcom has also obtained the rights to distribute South Korean firm Gamevil Inc.'s "Nom 2" mobile action game. It will be available for downloads through Capcom's home page for wireless phones starting Thursday.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 13:57 ET (17:57 GMT)

Headline: Softbank Mobile, DoCoMo To Boost Retail Store Lineups -Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--Softbank Mobile Corp. and NTT DoCoMo Inc. (9437.TO) plan to boost the capability of stores that market handsets compatible with their cellular phone services in a bid to regain the market share they lost to KDDI Corp. (9433.TO) after the mobile-number portability system started in October 2006, The Nikkei reported in its Sunday edition.   KDDI-compatible handsets are currently sold at 3,400 outlets nationwide, compared to 1,900 for Softbank Mobile and about 2,200 for DoCoMo. The mobile-number portability system, which allows cellular phone users to switch carriers without changing phone numbers, greatly benefited KDDI, which lured subscribers away from both of its rivals.   Softbank Mobile intends to boost the number of shops handling phones for its service to over 2,000 by the end of the year as well as have existing ones renovated and enlarged, with the aim of boosting the number of customers they can serve at one time by 70% to about 10,000 by the end of March, from about 6,000 now.   The necessary building and other costs will be borne by the retailers that operate the stores, with Softbank Mobile helping by introducing them to financial institutions willing to extend loans to pay for the changes, among other means.   DoCoMo plans to raise the proportion of high-end shops in Tokyo and nine nearby prefectures that have sufficient space to provide customer consultation and support and display handsets to about 50% by the end of March, from the current 30%.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 13:53 ET (17:53 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Profile: Investing For A Rainy Day
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By J.R. Brandstrader   Talking With   Bruce Berkowitz   President   Fairholme Capital Management     Let the bad times roll. That's a chilling mantra for an equity investor, especially one who hasn't sold any stocks short. Yet it defines the defensive posture of Bruce Berkowitz, president of Fairholme Capital Management and manager of the Fairholme Fund (ticker: FAIRX), a $4.6 billion multi-cap growth fund poised to outperform even in difficult markets. "We are very focused on notlosing money," says Berkowitz, 48, who was named runner-up in 2006 as Morningstar's domestic stock-fund manager of the year.   The Fairholme philosophy bears an uncanny resemblance to that of Warren Buffett, chairman of the fund's largest holding, Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA), which makes up 14% of managed assets. Buffett, says Berkowitz, "configures Berkshire Hathaway for bad environments. It has $40 billion of cash."   Berkowitz and his partners, Larry Pitkowsky, 42, and Keith Trauner, 49, keep about 20% of their portfolio in cash and much of the rest in 10 stocks. But their conservatism hasn't hurt them -- or their fellow investors.   Though Fairholme is performing in line with the market this year, the fund has trumped the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index over three and five years. It returned 19.21% in the three-year span ended May 3, versus the S&P's 12.42%, and 15.5% in the five-year period, against the S&P's 8.91%. Over the longer stretch, Fairholme has trounced 92% of its peers. Pitkowsky became co-manager in 2002, and Trauner is chief financial officer and treasurer.   Lipper gives the no-load fund top marks for total return, consistent return, capital preservation and expenses. Morningstar, which has awarded it a coveted five stars, thinks Fairholme investors ride in first class, because the fund-management company is focused on investment, not sales and marketing. It has an expense ratio of just 1%.   A graduate of the University of Massachusetts Amherst, Berkowitz worked at Lehman Brothers and Smith Barney before launching Fairholme. Mutual friends introduced him to Pitkowsky, but their professional relationship was cemented at a Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting. Berkowitz met Trauner at an annual meeting of Leucadia National (LUK), which investors regard as a small-scale version of Berkshire. The fund bought Leucadia in the single digits; it now trades in the low 30s.   Berkowitz, Pitkowsky and Trauner have long shared the same investment approach: Buy good management and good businesses at low prices relative to estimated free cash flow and intrinsic value. Berkowitz says Fairholme has been buying Berkshire stock since the fund's inception, including recently. He thinks the company's intrinsic value is "somewhere around $140,000 per share," well above its current quote, $108,600.   Fairholme has had exceedingly low turnover of around 20% a year, reflecting its long-term investment horizon. "Selling a stock is like getting divorced," Berkowitz says, noting the Fairholme team tracks five or six years of speeches, filings, Webcasts and reports produced by the companies whose shares it buys. It sells if the price of a stock climbs to a level at which future returns are likely to be no better than risk-free investments like Treasuries, or if management changes.   "We spend a lot of time trying to understand the psychology of the CEO's toys -- the trains, the planes -- and their thinking," he says. "We are very much about the jockey. If you want to understand owner-managers, you have to figure out how they managed through a difficult time, during an industry or general recession."   Fairholme's stable is filled with Buffett-like owner-managers, including lawyer-turned-financier N. Murray Edwards, 47, part-owner of the Calgary Flames hockey team and a member of numerous oil- and gas-company boards. Edwards built Canadian Natural Resources (CNQ) from scratch; it now boasts a market capitalization of more than $33 billion.   The fund started buying shares in 2004 at around 20 apiece. The stock now trades for 63 and accounts for almost 15% of Fairholme's assets. "Within a couple of years, free cash flow per share could approach $10, assuming somewhat lower commodity prices than exist today," Berkowitz says.   Canadian Natural Resources recently renewed a share-repurchase program for up to 5% of its outstanding stock.   Fairholme also has money on another company Edwards helped found and grow: Penn West Energy Trust (PWE). Edwards recently left the board after the trust merged with Petrofund Energy Trust. "We started buying [Penn West] in late 2003 and early 2004, at prices between 10 and 15 a share, and made it a bigger holding in 2005 at higher prices," Berkowitz says.   He estimates the trust's net asset value is somewhat higher than its current market value, and contends that "investors are not giving it enough credit for two large off-balance-sheet assets that are just starting to be developed." Seal, a 300,000-acre oil-sands property, is believed to hold 6.8 billion barrels of oil, while Pembina is a mature light sweet oil field from which the company could realize between 150 million and 400 million barrels.   Charlie Ergen, 54, chairman of EchoStar Communications (DISH), is another owner-manager of the sort Berkowitz loves. Fairholme bought EchoStar in the high-20s per share from mid-2005 to early 2006, a time of great uncertainty for pay-TV distribution companies, especially those in the DBS/Satellite industry. The stock now trades for about 49. Berkowitz wagers the company's free cash flow could approach $5 a share after taxes "in a couple of years," up from around $3 now.   Fairholme also was attracted to copper giant Phelps Dodge despite concerns about management. "We got it at an incredibly cheap price, and [the presence of] activist shareholders gave us confidence that shareholders would be protected," Pitkowsky says. The company was purchased in March for $26 billion, or $128.68 a share, by Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold (FCX).   Fairholme picked up most of its Phelps Dodge shares in the spring and summer of 2006, at prices ranging from the high-70s to mid-80s. At the time, says Berkowitz, the company's "unhedged cash flow per share was approaching $20."   The Fairholme team plans to hang on to the Freeport-McMoRan shares it received in exchange for its Phelps Dodge stock. "It looks attractive to us because of demand from China and 20 years of underinvestment in new copper facilities," said Trauner.   Freeport-McMoRan said last week that its first-quarter profit came close to doubling, due to rising metals prices and the acquisition of Phelps Dodge. If commodities prices hold at current levels, the company's free cash flow could climb to more than $7 per share from a current $6, Pitkowsky says.   Given Fairholme's evident talent for picking winners, why the side bet on cash? Typically cash averages 20% of the portfolio, though it currently accounts for 24%. "We think cash is a strategic asset for the fund," Berkowitz says. "Though we would eagerly become fully invested under the right circumstances, shareholders have benefited to date from holding some cash."   Twenty-four percent isn't "some," but it's hard to argue with Fairholme's sterling record.   ---   J.R. Brandstrader, a free-lance writer, contributes frequently to Barron's.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:10 ET (04:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: EMI In Three-Way US Private Equity Bidding War - FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.S. private equity firms Fortress (FIG), Cerberus (CRP.XX) and One Equity are set for a GBP3 billion battle for control of recorded music giant EMI (EMI.LN) during the next two weeks, the Financial Times reported on Saturday.   According to the FT, all three have sent letters expressing their interest in buying the music group. EMI will open its books to all three bidders, which are expected to make their presentations to the board next week, the FT reported. Stipulations from EMI mean that the three firms will only have until May 23 to make their fully-financed, formal offers.   If the bids are not satisfactory, EMI will press ahead with a securitization of its music publishing assets, the FT says. The private equity firms' moves are being closely followed by Warner Music (WMG), whose own "nonbinding" proposal at 260 pence a share was rejected in early March.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 07:02 ET (11:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Darden Restaurants Offers Barbecue Chain For Sale, Better Positioning Casual Dining Leader For Future Growth
Story: Darden to help affected Smokey Bones employees       ORLANDO, Fla., May 5 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Darden Restaurants, Inc. (NYSE: DRI) today announced the closure of 56 Smokey Bones Barbeque & Grill restaurants. Darden will offer the remaining 73 restaurants for sale - all located primarily in the eastern half of the United States.        (Logo: http://www.newscom.com/cgi-bin/prnh/20050203/FLTH026LOGO)     The action comes as part of an overall effort by the company to better position Darden for future growth. Smokey Bones has lagged the performance of Darden's other brands as the barbecue concept's core guests chose to dine at Smokey Bones with less frequency.     The company had been testing the possibility of converting some units to a new format called Rocky River Grillhouse. That longer-term test featuring fire-grilled foods was predicated on Smokey Bones' ability to stabilize its business.  Long-term performance declines, however, continued and recently accelerated, making that test not viable.     "This action in no way reflects adversely on the hard work of people associated with Smokey Bones and we will take care of every employee affected by this action," said Darden Chairman and CEO Clarence Otis. "The remaining Smokey Bones restaurants are a viable business, but one that is not consistent with Darden's vision for a national restaurant concept."     Remaining Smokey Bones restaurants are located primarily in the South, Mid-Atlantic, Midwest and New England.     The decision to sell Smokey Bones allows Darden to better focus its efforts on more productive businesses that will provide stronger opportunities for employees, said Drew Madsen, Darden's president and chief operating officer. The company will carefully evaluate each closing restaurant to determine whether it is suitable for use by one of Darden's other restaurant brands, and will begin marketing the remainder immediately.     "Many of these closed restaurants are valuable locations," Madsen said. "They just didn't work as barbecue restaurants.  We expect these properties to serve the public again as vibrant restaurants and retail businesses."     Darden will give 4,000 employees who worked at closed Smokey Bones restaurants opportunities to transfer to other Darden locations.  And for those who leave the company, Darden will provide support to help their transition.     "Darden is doing the difficult things required to grow," Otis said. "The company's long-term growth goals remain unchanged."     Darden, headquartered in Orlando, FL, owns and operates about 1,400 Red Lobster, Olive Garden, Bahama Breeze, Smokey Bones, and Seasons 52(R) restaurants. The company is the 25th largest employer in the United States with 160,000 employees. It is also the world's largest casual dining company with $5.7 billion in annual sales. Headline: Barron's(5/7) Our Day In The Sun, Sorta
Story: (From BARRON'S)   The New York Times did its usual comprehensive job last Wednesday covering Rupert Murdoch's surprise $5 billion bid for Dow Jones. But we at Barron's, at least, noticed a curious discrepancy in a graphic montage that was part of the package.   Among pictures of various Dow Jones publications, the graphic showed a purported Barron's front page dated March 3, 2003, with the headline "Barron's on Bankmark." We all drew a blank. Our cover story in that issue was actually apiece on Cathay Pacific, with utterly different art.   Worried that disgraced Times scribe Jason Blair might've infiltrated the art department, we called the paper's design chief. He surmised that some staffers, out later in the week, had picked what they thought was a legitimate image from Google, where the befuddling cover does indeed feature prominently.   "Look, screw-ups happen, especially when one is not careful picking stuff off the Web," he explained equably. "I will chastise them Monday when they come back to work."   No need to. We all make mistakes. But if they had asked, we could have loaned them a real copy of Barron's.   -- JONATHAN R. LAING   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) European Trader: The Stakes Rise Sharply For Barclays
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Arindam Nag and Matthew Curtin   A Dutch court's freeze on the sale of ABN Amro's LaSalle Bank to Bank of America gives Royal Bank of Scotland and its partners an advantage over rival Barclays in the bidding for ABN.   It's also a big win for ABN (ticker: ABN) investors, who now have a choice in deciding the future of their bank, rather than being railroaded into accepting management's preferred option. Bank of America (BAC), which had agreed to pay a net $16 billion for LaSalle, has reason to be angry.   The LaSalle sale would have made ABN less attractive to the RBS consortium, furthering the Dutch company's goal of being bought instead by Barclays (BCS). RBS contends that the LaSalle sale can't proceed without ABN shareholder approval; ABN asserts that it can.   Bank of America is highly unlikely to get anywhere by suing ABN over the blocked deal. For one thing, a court -- not ABN -- froze Barclay's sale of LaSalle. And even if BofA somehow moves the litigation into a U.S. court, its chance of overturning the ruling seems slim, given that ABN is domiciled in the Netherlands. In addition, it should be fairly easy to argue that the LaSalle sale was effectively a poison pill to prevent a rival bid for ABN from succeeding.   There are multiple potential outcomes to this fraught takeover battle. The most obvious: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS.U.K.) offers ABN more for LaSalle than BofA is willing to pay. But RBS makes its bid contingent on buying all of ABN. In essence, it ends up paying itself. ABN's Dutch retail business probably would then go to Royal Bank's consortium partner Fortis (FORA.Netherlands), a Dutch-Belgian bank, while Spain's Banco Santander (STD) would buy ABN's Brazilian and Italian operations.   Another possibility: Barclays revises its original all-share offer. Add a cash component -- possibly followed by a rights issue, to balance the leverage on its balance sheet -- and you might have a credible counteroffer to the RBS-led consortium's.   In any case, the stakes have gotten higher for Barclays. If it loses ABN, it could become a target itself, with perhaps BofA as its leading hunter. After all, the U.K. bank's bid for ABN -- with which it has few geographic overlaps -- indicates that it is running out of immediate internal growth opportunities. Moreover, Barclays' shares currently trade at roughly 8.4 times forward earnings, around a 6% discount to its peers.   The Dutch judge has given ABN until mid-June to appeal the move, ample time for both bidding parties to revisit their strategies. The only immediate loser after Thursday's ruling is ABN's management, for whom the court decision is a direct snub.   News Corp., which launched a takeover bid last week for Dow Jones, Barron's parent, isn't the only Rupert Murdoch property making stock-market news these days.   BSkyB's New York-traded American depositary shares (BSY) were fetching 50.32 at midday Friday, about 25% above where they began the year. Why?   True, the U.K. satellite broadcaster recently reported good first-quarter earnings, but it also disclosed that its marketing costs had jumped and that its customer-churn rate is on the rise. And it is facing multiple legal and regulatory challenges to its latest strategic moves.   BSkyB might yet have to sell its stake in cable's ITV at a loss and see the terrestrial broadcaster fall into the hands of rival Virgin Media, which has taken BSkyB to court in a dispute over the supplying of basic Sky channels to the cable company. And the success of ITV and Setanta Sports in outbidding the BBC and BSkyB for rights to show the FA Cup, English soccer's top knockout competition, is an ominous sign of growing competition.   But investors seem to have concluded that BSkyB has crossed a critical threshold. Capital spending is leveling off after the broadcaster's initial broadband and high-definition TV assault, while subscriber growth is accelerating and the company is taking a bigger share of U.K. television advertising, even if that pie is shrinking.   BSkyB says its gross direct-to-home customer additions were the highest in a fiscal third quarter in six years. At 340,000, the total exceeded even bullish forecasts. Churn did worsen, but BSkyB points to the phasing-out of discounts that cost it some business, short-term, and left net new customer additions at a more modest 51,000. But those new customers seem to be buying higher-priced products, with average revenue per user coming in above 400 British pounds for the first time.   All this promises extra earnings growth, perhaps not fully reflected in the admittedly robust 21 times forward earnings multiple that BSkyB's stock has been trading at.   That said, BSkyB now faces much higher expectations of its operating performance, suggesting that any slippage will be judged harshly by investors.   ---   Arindam Nag, who is based in London, and Matthew Curtin, who writes from Paris, are contributors to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---   DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES     Region/   Country    DJ Global          DJ Global          DJ Global     Point     Indexes,           Indexes,           Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg. Headline: Kenya Airways Says Plane Missing After Takeoff; Carrying 115
Story: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP)--Kenya Airways said a plane that went missing after takeoff Saturday was carrying 115 people.   Kenya Airways lost contact with a 737-800 aircraft that took off from Cameroon early Saturday, it said.   "We have no details about what has happened to the aircraft," Kenya Airways (KAL.NR) CEO Titus Naikuni said.   "The last message from the aircraft was received by the control tower in Douala immediately after take-off," Kenya Airways said on its Web site.   The flight departed Douala at 12:05 a.m. and was to arrive in Nairobi at 06:15 a.m.   The airline said it opened a crisis management center near the airport.   The announcement was signed by Michael Okwiri, of Kenya Airways corporate communications.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 02:38 ET (06:38 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Research Reports: How Analysts Size -2-
Story: Outperform   -- Price 63.12 on May 1   by Bear Stearns     Target: 76. Yum! reported 1Q EPS of 70 cents, well ahead of our 60-cent estimate and consensus 64 cents . . . the real drivers were strong results in China and YRI -- [non-China international restaurants]. Taco Bell results were worse than expected, with same-store sales down 11% as the brand suffered from the December E. coli problem and NYC rodent video in February. But overall, U.S. operating income was down just 11% or . . . 17% excluding other income effects. China and YRI operating income grew 31% and 25%, respectively, outweighing U.S. issues. Yum! raised full-year EPS guidance to $3.23, from $3.21. We're raising our '07 EPS estimate to $3.27 from $3.21.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Popcorn, Soda, Shrek III And Old -2-
Story: A: I own the Journal Register [JRC], which publishes weekly newspapers, local newspapers and local content. It's based in Yardley, Pa. They just sold some papers at about 10 times Ebitda. They are selling at eight times earnings and they just had a poor quarter. They are affected by housing and auto sales. It's the worst possible environment for them now, but the cash flows are excellent.     Q: Any others?   A: McClatchy [MNI] is hitting new lows in a booming market on the same basis.     Q: They just reported disappointing results.   A: Yes, and it is now selling at lower multiples of earnings, even on the lower projected earnings, than it ever has. It has got big book value. It has got great cash flows. It has good management. So the bet is at these lower levels, a good management begins to identify more with the new environment and build up Internet-related activities. Next year is an election year, and that tightens up the advertising environment. The rates tend to be better, and people tend to read more newspapers, be more aware of what's going on. There should be a cyclical pop next year. But near term, they could be seen as "value traps." You have wonderful assets generating lots of cash, but no visible growth.     Q: Are you confident it isn't a value trap?   A: I'm not. That is the risk you take. This is known as the stock market. But I've got cash flows working in my favor, and the upside is the companies use the cash flows to pay down debt and create new vehicles to create an earnings pattern that will help the stock price of these companies appreciate. Newsprint costs are coming down, too.     Q: Any other ideas?   A: I'm buying banks in the farming communites because of the booming farm economy. I won't mention names because I'm in the process of buying. The banking industry is depressed because of the subprime situation, fear of recession, bad loans, but these are healthy companies. The balance sheets are terrific. The ratios are good. The earnings are consistent. They have been showing higher earnings, and yet the stocks are down. They should be doing well, because it is a very prosperous time for farmers.     Q: Thanks, Buzz.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Qantas Deal In Uncharted Territory; Takeover Panel Holds Key
Story: By Lyndal McFarland   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     SYDNEY (Dow Jones)--The Macquarie Bank Ltd.-led (MBL.AU) bid for Qantas Airways Ltd. (QAN.AU) was up in the air Saturday, with Australia's Takeovers Panel considering whether to allow the consortium to proceed with its A$10.8 billion offer for the airline.   The Airline Partners Australia consortium, which includes U.S. buyout group TPG Inc., is seeking permission from the panel to continue with its bid for the airline after receiving a late acceptance for its A$5.45 a share offer, pushing its interest in the airline over the key 50%-level.   The world's largest airline takeover looked to have failed late Friday after APA said acceptances fell short of 50% - the level necessary to trigger an automatic two week extension of the bid - by the 0900 GMT Friday deadline.   A person familiar with the situation said at the time the acceptance level for the offer had reached 46%.   "However, subsequently on Friday, APA received an acceptance from a large investor, which would be sufficient to take acceptances for Qantas shares to more than 50%. APA intends to make submissions to the Takeovers Panel to allow the offer to continue," APA said.   A spokeswoman for the APA consortium declined to give further details, including who the large shareholder was and what time the acceptance arrived.   Unsourced local media reports said U.S. corporate raider Samuel Heyman, who had built up a 10% stake in the airline, had failed to accept the offer by the deadline. Without citing sources, The Australian newspaper said APA had expected Heyman to accept.   It is not known whether the late acceptance came from Heyman.   Officials from Macquarie were not immediately available for comment.   The Takeovers Panel called an emergency meeting Saturday to consider the bidders' plea, a person familiar with the situation said. The person did not indicate how long the panel could take to make a decision, although they said a ruling was unlikely Saturday.     APA Situation Unprecedented; Outcome Uncertain     "We don't believe the APA is over the line," BBY analyst Fabian Babich said.   "Technically, the offer closed at 7.00 pm (local time) and what we have here is an unprecedented event. We are in uncharted waters," Babich said   Babich said from a commercial perspective, it may not matter that the bid was late, but the key consideration by the Takeovers Panel will be whether any party will be hurt by the situation.   "There're all sorts of considerations that the Takeovers Panel has to take into account," he said. He noted that while Qantas shares were not trading, the credit default swap market traded wildly in the wake of the developments.   "In making the decision, because it is a first, it will be a precedent setting decision and they will have to consider it very, very carefully," Babich said. "We thought this one would be a photo finish, but we had nothing like this in mind," he added.   The Qantas board also held an emergency meeting Saturday and said afterwards it will make a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange before trade starts on Monday. It did not specify the exact timing of the statement.   If the panel rules against the consortium, and deems the late application as unacceptable, APA will drop the A$5.45 a share bid, which was strongly supported by Qantas' board. This is expected to prompt calls for the resignation of members, including Chief Executive Officer Geoff Dixon and Chairwoman Margaret Jackson, who readily embraced the takeover offer.   The offer for Qantas, a former state-owned national carrier fondly known as the Flying Kangaroo, was one of the largest and most controversial takeover bids in Australia's corporate history.   Even before Friday's deadline, APA was forced to revise its bid a month ago due to shareholder dissatisfaction at the offer price.   BBY's Babich expects Qantas shares to nosedive if the consortium is told it cannot progress with the offer.   If that happens, analysts say shares are likely to fall below A$5.00. Many of the airlines' shares are held by hedge funds, who are seen as likely to quickly sell down their holdings in the wake of the bid's failure.   Qantas shares closed up 1 cent Friday at A$5.38.   Babich said if the panel does not reach a decision by Monday, trading in Qantas shares will almost certainly be suspended on the Australian Stock Exchange.   Qantas has upgraded earnings twice since the bid was launched six months ago, and the airline continues to report strong passenger growth. In its statement Saturday, the Qantas board said it is confident that the various businesses in the group "continue to operate in a highly professional manner."     -By Lyndal McFarland, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-2-8235-2957; lyndal.mcfarland@dowjones.com   -Edited by Alan Soughley     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 02:14 ET (06:14 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(5/5) Trade In ABN Shares Draws Review By UK Regulator
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Carrick Mollenkamp, Ann Carrns, Alistair MacDonald and Jason Singer   The United Kingdom's financial-services regulator has begun a preliminary review of hedge-fund trading in ABN Amro Holding NV shares shortly before a recent takeover bid by a consortium of European banks led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC, according to people familiar with the situation.   Separately, Bank of America Corp. filed a lawsuit against ABN seeking to enforce its $21 billion agreement to buy the Dutch firm's LaSalle Bank unit in the U.S. That deal stemmed from ABN's earlier agreement to be bought by Britain's Barclays PLC for $89.9 billion in stock.   People familiar with the hedge-fund inquiry said Britain's Financial Services Authority is looking into trading that took place shortly before the consortium of European banks disclosed on April 25 that it intended to bid about 39 euros ($52.87) a share, or 72.27 billion euros ($98 billion), for ABN. The consortium and ABN in recent days have struck a conciliatory chord in discussing that bid. A bid had been expected Friday night but it may not arrive until Saturday morning or as late as Sunday as RBS scrambles to finalize one, according to people familiar with the situation.   One trade under review, according to these people, involves the purchase of about 100 million euros in ABN shares by London hedge fund Toscafund Asset Management LLP on April 24. The next day, after the RBS-led consortium announced its bid, ABN shares rose 3.5% in Amsterdam.   The consortium's desire to bid for ABN was well-known at the time of the Toscafund purchase. The RBS group issued a statement April 13 disclosing its interest. People familiar with the situation said the FSA probe, which started within the past week, is preliminary. A spokesman for the FSA declined comment, as did a spokeswoman for RBS.   Toscafund, which has $4.5 billion under management and specializes in investments in financial firms, is owned by Old Oak Holdings Ltd., according to U.K. corporate records. Old Oak's nonexecutive chairman is George Mathewson, the former chairman and chief executive of RBS.   A Toscafund spokesman said the fund doesn't comment on its portfolio. During RBS's annual meeting April 25, the day RBS announced its bid for ABN, Mr. Mathewson said in an interview that Toscafund owned about 1% of ABN. He also said the hedge fund supported RBS's consortium bid and that he hadn't discussed the proposed offer with his successor at RBS, Fred Goodwin.   A Toscafund spokesman said Mr. Mathewson isn't involved in any investment decisions of Toscafund.   Dutch regulator Autoriteit Financiele Markten, or AFM, also is conducting an inquiry into stock trading tied to ABN. A possible focus is how hedge funds gathered information amid the fight for ABN, according to people familiar with that probe.   Meanwhile, Bank of America's suit, filed in U.S. District Court in New York, further complicated the complex merger scenario unfolding on two continents.   Bank of America, the second-largest U.S. bank by stock-market value, claimed it has the legal right to buy Chicago-based LaSalle and sought an injunction blocking ABN from selling LaSalle to anyone else or even negotiating with other potential buyers, except under the conditions specified in their original agreement. Bank of America, based in Charlotte, N.C., also seeks unspecified monetary damages.   ABN Amro declined to comment on the suit.   ABN "is contractually obligated to proceed with the LaSalle transaction whether or not it merges with Barclays [or any other party or no party at all]," Bank of America said in the lawsuit.   The legal action followed a ruling a day earlier by a Dutch court that ordered ABN to halt the sale of LaSalle until ABN shareholders can vote on the transaction. ABN agreed to the sale to bolster its original agreement to be taken over by Barclays.   Under the agreement between Bank of America and ABN, another buyer -- such as the consortium led by RBS -- has until Sunday to offer a competing bid for LaSalle. Bank of America would then have five business days to match the higher offer. If Bank of America declined to match that offer, it is entitled to a substantial breakup fee.   In its suit, Bank of America said ABN has breached "representations and warranties" in its agreement to sell LaSalle, because ABN had assured Bank of America that it had the authority to sell LaSalle without any shareholder vote. As a result, the suit says, Bank of America has suffered "substantial harm."   Amid those maneuvers, ABN and the RBS group have become much more friendly. ABN and the consortium have several working groups toiling around the clock to assist the Royal Bank team in coming up with a firm rival bid, people familiar with the situation said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:00 ET (04:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) A Clean Bill Of Health -2-
Story: Yet Schaeffer was succeeded as chairman and CEO by Anthem alumnus Larry Glasscock, a 59-year-old former banker best known for his amiability and skill in "relationship management." According to some observers, the integration of more than a dozen disparate computer systems -- a legacy of past WellPoint/Anthem acquisition blitzes -- has languished somewhat under Glasscock. Product innovation has likewise flagged.   But that might be about to change. Last February, Glasscock announced his intention to give up his posts as president and CEO at the beginning of June, though he would remain chairman. Named by the board to fill the two positions was dark horse Angela Braly, WellPoint's current executive vice president and general counsel.   Wall Street was stunned. CIBC analyst Carl McDonald called the move "a curve out of left field." Most analysts were betting on Colby, their long-time contact at the company. Yet Colby tells Barron's and whoever else asks that he's perfectly comfortable with Braly's promotion and has no plans to leave the company.   In fact, Braly is likely to surprise the skeptics with her creativity and drive, several sources told Barron's. Moreover, her background in corporate law and public affairs make her an ideal advocate for the company in the battles that likely loom, particularly if the Democrats by 2009 control both the White House and Congress. Universal coverage for America's 47 million uninsured is among the hot-button issues.   WellPoint and other managed-care companies are no longer as demonized as they were in the 'Nineties for unfairly rationing care and penny-pinching by booting new mothers out of maternity wards after 24 hours. But the battle is now about to be joined between the all-government health-care jihadists and the proponents of the competitive, free-market health model.   We suspect that the managed care industry will fare well in the struggle. And that, at least, will be good news to WellPoint's shareholders.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:10 ET (04:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Fund Of Information: Gross: Unfazed After 20 Years
Story: (From BARRON'S)   By Lawrence C. Strauss   Twenty years ago this week, bill gross rolled out the Pimco Total Return Fund (ticker: PTTRX). Gross wasn't the superstar he is today. But the timing of the launch turned out to be right on the money.   Interest rates were coming down, boosting bond prices. Gross and his crew put a bigger weighting on price appreciation than on yield.   That sometimes meant buying bonds with longer maturities and durations -- "in some cases, a sacrifice of yield relative to price potential," he says. And "people just didn't view bonds moving in price," Gross, Pimco's managing director, told Barron's in an interview last week. "They were viewed in terms of their yield."   As the fund name attests, Gross emphasized total return -- a combination of yield and price-appreciation -- continuing an investment philosophy that the Newport Beach, Calif., bond shop had developed on the institutional side.   Gross was on the right side of a secular trend. Rates continued to fall, and the fund has been very popular with investors. It now has about $103 billion in assets, the largest bond fund in the U.S.   From its inception until April 30, the fund's institutional share class had an annual return of 8.28%, besting the 7.52% gain of the Lehman Aggregate Bond Index (which measures investment-grade bonds), according to Morningstar.   Gross was a big believer in derivatives. Pimco had started using futures in the early 1980s. Interest-rate swaps followed.   The latest derivatives phase surfaced more recently, with credit-default swaps, collateralized debt obligations and indexes tracking those products. "We've trailed the enthusiasm for many of these recent products, if only because they have been introduced at a time when their yields aren't that attractive," says Gross, a member of the Barron's Roundtable.   Credit spreads remain tight, and many yield-hungry investors have chased riskier assets. "The trade has been to jump on the bandwagon, and I sort of wish we had," admits Gross. "The problem is that, from today's starting point, the valuations are extremely high and you are not getting much in return for the potential risk that you take."   He maintains that the explosion of derivatives in recent years allows the global financial system to "lay off" some of the risk, but "the problem is that these derivatives, by their nature and design, are inherently leveraged."   Gross sees a "strong global economy but a weak U.S. economy that's predicated primarily on housing," and he expects the Fed to cut rates later this year, most likely by a quarter or half percentage point. He warns, however, that "there's limited total return over the next six to 12 months."   The fund's girth, which some say has limited his selection of securities, doesn't faze Gross. "We can still do whatever we want to do," he says, pointing out that the swaps and futures markets are very liquid.   His record does have a few blemishes. Gross didn't think the Fed would raise rates as much as it did in recent years, and he exited corporate bonds "a little early." Still, his smarts and savvy have far outweighed his mistakes. Just ask anyone who invested in Total Return 20 years ago.   ---   E-mail: lawrence.strauss@barrons.com   ---                          Scoreboard                        Edging Out the S&P     Equity-income funds have gained 17.72% in the past year, a little ahead of  the S&P 500's 16.67% total return, according to Lipper, the fund-tracking  arm of Reuters.
