Headline: Barron's(5/7) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining more than 5% of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from April 19 through 25. Source: Dow Jones Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     PHH (PHH)   Pennant Capital Management opposes a merger with GE Capital Solutions and Blackstone Group because, it contends, the price doesn't reflectPHH's value. Pennant said the merger isn't in the best interest of the shareholders, and it urged the board to pursue a separation of the company's mortgage and fleet businesses through a spinoff. Pennant holds 4,169,800 shares (7.8% of the total outstanding).     Hexcel (HXL)   O.S.S. Capital Management asked the company to form a committee of independent directors and retain an investment bank to advise the committee to maximize shareholder value. O.S.S. said HXL is "under-earning," and the shareholders are "suffering from this situation." O.S.S. Capital currently holds 4.81 million shares (5.1%).     Riviera Holdings (RIV)   Flag Leisure Group intends to nominate a slate of five directors to the board at the 2007 annual meeting of stockholders. The nominees are Michael D. Rumbolz, chief executive of Las Vegas cash-access company Cash Systems (CKNN); Larry duBoef, a former president of the American Cancer Society; Dan Reichartz, the general partner of DR&DR, a private firm that provides strategic planning, marketing and management services to the gaming, hotel and resort industry; Thalia M. Dondero, who serves on the Board of Regents of the Nevada System of Higher Education; and Daniel Yih, chief operating officer of private-equity firm GTCR Golder Rauner. The Flag Leisure Group sent a letter to the company demanding access to a list of stockholders and other related materials for the purpose of soliciting proxies. The Flag Leisure Group currently holds 836,588 shares (6.71%).     Universal Power Group (UPG)   3V Capital Management asked UPG for representation on its board. 3V Capital also requested a meeting with the company's board to discuss its views with regard to creating shareholder value and improving the market's impression of its intrinsic value.   It also said that it wants to work "constructively and consensually" with Universal Power's executive management team and board to help "refine" the company's business strategy and operating plan and "better communicate" it to the investor community.   3V Capital currently holds 628,700 shares (12.6%).     Lamson & Sessions (LMS)   A group including Ramius Capital Group called for the company to promptly set a date for its 2007 annual meeting or add two of its representatives to the board.   The Ramius group said it believes that the board may have delayed scheduling the 2007 annual meeting because of the exploration of strategic alternatives currently under way.   The Ramius group currently holds 1,569,338 shares (9.9%).     Increases in Holdings     DHB Industries (DHBT)   A group including Harbinger Capital Partners Master Fund I raised its holdings to 6,833,225 shares (13.4%), after buying 933,701 from April 24 to 26 at $5.37 to $5.57 each.     Decreases in Holdings     US Airways Group (LCC)   PAR Investment Partners, US Airways' largest shareholder, cut its stake to 268,485 (0.29%) after selling 6.75 million shares to UBS Securities (UBS).  No other details of the transaction were disclosed.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 30 Japanese Auditing Firms To End Work For Listed Cos -Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--Of the 270 or so auditing firms in Japan that perform services for listed companies, about 30 plan to stop doing such work in the current fiscal year, The Nikkei reported in its Sunday edition.   Auditing firms have been ordered by the Financial Services Agency to improve the quality of their work in order to increase the credibility of their clients' financial statements, something that is hard for some smaller auditors to do because of a lack of qualified personnel.   The Japanese Institute of Certified Public Accountants has enacted a rule requiring auditing firms, starting from fiscal 2007, to register with it if they work for listed companies. About 160 firms, including major ones, registered by the end of April, but about 30, mainly those employing only one certified public accountant, have declined to register. About 80 firms have yet to make their intentions clear, and have until the end of July to do so.   Among auditing firms with at least five CPAs, Universal Audit Firm has opted against registering, forcing clients JP-Holdings Inc. (2749.JA) and Miyako Inc. (3424.JA), both listed on the Jasdaq Securities Exchange, to hire new auditors.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 14:58 ET (18:58 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Stem Cells' Powerful Promise
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   Daniel Kerner could speak in complete sentences and sing nursery rhymes by the time he was two. So his parents were baffled when his speech began to deteriorate. Then his motor skills started to falter until one day, when he was 4, Daniel had to crawl off the school bus that dropped him off at his suburban Southern California home.   -- Doctors diagnosed the boy with Batten disease, a rare degenerative disorder in which the brain stops producing enzymes needed to clear cellular waste that accumulates and grows toxic. Afflicted children become blind, bedridden and demented; very few live to their teens.   -- So on Nov. 14, 2006, Daniel became the first volunteer in a risky clinical procedure. Over eight hours at a Portland, Ore., hospital, doctors drilled a hole in his skull and injected his brain with neural stem cells collected and purified by a small biotechnology company called StemCells. Doctors hoped these cells would grow into healthy, enzyme-producing tissue.   -- It's too soon to call the surgery a success. But within a month, Daniel's parents noticed he made more eye contact. Then Daniel said "Dad" for the first time in two years.   -- "He was just a kid waiting to die, and he was given a gift of life," says his father, Marcus Kerner, an assistant U.S. attorney and lieutenant colonel in the Air Force Reserve. Today, "Daniel is getting stronger steadily and very excited when he tries to talk." For his seventh birthday earlier this year, and with help from an instructor and special equipment, Daniel went skiing at Mammoth Mountain, a resort in the eastern part of his home state.   Minor miracles like Daniel's are why stem cells inspire so much hope -- and hype. Both will intensify this year as money pours in from states and private donors, as the political climate becomes more supportive and as small biotech companies -- many of them long on promise yet short on profit -- seek to capitalize on this wave of optimism. Investors would be well advised to pay close attention, particularly to companies whose products support the research effort, but to proceed carefully -- and with patience -- as the science develops.   Already, some companies are lining up clinical trials this year to test how stem cells -- primal cells that can grow quickly into different tissues -- will affect patients suffering from cancer, heart disease and spinal-cord injury. But the scope extends beyond life-threatening ailments; the San Diego company Cytori Therapeutics (ticker: CYTX), for example, is testing 19 patients in Japan to see how stem cells extracted from fat can reconstruct breast tissue after mastectomies.   "We don't even know what the potential scope or limits are," says Arnold Kriegstein, director of the Institute for Regenerative Medicine at the University of California (San Francisco) and a founding director of Columbia University's Neural Stem Cell Center. "But we're at a transformative moment, and stem cells could change what we know of medicine."   So what gives stem cells their biological potency? While the human body has many types of cells -- bone, blood, nerve and muscle, among others -- stem cells are versatile primary units that can divide, differentiate and grow into other specialized cells. These include adult stem cells, found in bone marrow, blood or other body parts, as well as embryonic stem cells, which come from human embryos and, as such, carry more ethical baggage.   Human embryonic stem cells were first extracted in 1998 (by researchers at the University of Wisconsin), so the science is still young. Embryonic stem cells -- culled, for example, from unused embryos at in vitro fertilization clinics -- are controversial, since their extraction destroys the embryo. But scientists also believe they hold greater potential for self renewal and can grow into more complex organs.   It is a measure of how much is unknown that scientists differ widely when asked the time it would take to develop a marketable human embryonic stem-cell treatment, with answers ranging from three to 30 years. Among the obstacles: transplanted embryonic stem cells in animal experiments that sprouted unwanted hair, teeth and tumors -- a sign that scientists haven't fully figured out how to coax them to grow only into specific cells.   In comparison, more limited therapies using adult stem cells are expected to reach the market sooner. In fact, some of these have already produced encouraging signs in early human trials designed to verify the treatments' safety, although not yet their effectiveness.   Researchers from Osiris Therapeutics (OSIR) recently injected bone-marrow-derived stem cells intravenously into 53 patients who had suffered heart attacks. Compared with those given a placebo, treated patients were four times less likely to suffer irregular heartbeats, and the "ejection fraction" -- a measure of the amount of blood a heart efficiently pumps -- improved. No one died. Next up: efficacy trials that involve hundreds or possibly thousands of patients.   In a separate, independent test in Brazil, 13 of 15 Type 1 diabetes patients who were treated with stem cells from their own blood were able to stop using insulin to maintain normal blood-sugar levels.   If Wall Street believes in following the money, much of its own private cash has gone to stem cells lately. And private-equity money could well follow as the science gathers momentum. "There's a whole developing field of socially responsible investing, and I think it hasn't yet looked at critically necessary medicine," says Robert Klein, the real-estate developer who was the driving force behind California's decision to fund stem-cell research. Within three years, more money should come from venture-capital investors, pensions with a social mandate, and the growing pool of socially responsible funds, Klein says.   Stem cells have already drawn the attention of large corporations. Genzyme's (GENZ) stance, for one, is fairly typical of big biotech's. The Cambridge, Mass., company is no stranger to cell-based treatment and therapy, having explored the field for more than a decade. "Cell and gene therapy in the last 20 years has tended to over-promise and under-deliver," says John McPherson, head of its biologic research. Still, Genzyme says it continues to study the field, and this includes watching for small promising companies to buy.   Others are moving in selectively, a sign they see future commercial potential. Merck (MRK) has provided funding in exchange for shares -- with warrants to buy more -- in Geron (GERN), a Menlo Park, Calif., biotech company that works with embryonic stem cells. Boston Scientific (BSX), which makes the nation's top-selling drug-coated heart stent, has a joint venture with Osiris to develop its stem-cell treatment for heart disease.   At the same time, symbiotic deals have sprouted between small stem-cell companies with emerging technology and large device makers with manufacturing muscle. General Electric's (GE) health-care unit has acquired exclusive global rights to distribute a device from ThermoGenesis (KOOL) that extracts and stores stem cells, while Japanese camera and equipment maker Olympus (7733.Japan) has a deal with Cytori to manufacture a machine Cytori designed to harvest stem cells from fat tissues.   This surge of interest from deeper-pocketed players is not lost on the small biotech companies struggling to turn their developing science into commercial payoffs. In fact, most companies are desperate to milk any goodwill -- one reason why investing in stem-cell companies can be treacherous.   For a start, most stem-cell companies have only a thin pipeline of one or two products -- usually based on hard-to-handicap science. Few are profitable. Almost all are burning through wads of cash and only too willing to use any means within reach to raise money needed to stay afloat. Advanced Cell Technology (ACTC) never seems to have taken a step too small to trumpet in a press release. (Recent example: The company's ability to rescue vision in blind rats was noted in Scientific American's March issue.)   Also, a major breakthrough, when it does arrive, might not come from a company whose shares currently trade.   No question, the payoff for picking right can be big. The $23 billion drug-discovery company Celgene (CELG) was once a small-cap stock before the Food and Drug Administration approved its Thalomid drug. As a result, speculation in stem-cell stocks is rife. Anticipation of imminent breakthroughs sent Geron shares above 75 in 2000; today they trade around 7. Few of these stocks attract the kind of long-term institutional investors that lend a stabilizing influence, and most jump and slide on mere mentions or rebuttals in medical journals, which makes them susceptible to academia's ego-driven swipes and snipes.   So where should an investor interested in a relatively pure stem-cell play begin?   From the outside, the squat, nondescript building that houses StemCells  in Palo Alto, Calif., looks just like a college lab. A trickling brook out front strives for a bucolic touch. There was no receptionist on a recent afternoon when a reporter came calling; the CFO himself answered the door.   The company with the industry's most coveted ticker symbol -- STEM -- is run like a lab; three-quarters of its 46 employees are in research. Its current Phase 1 trial for Batten disease ultimately will involve six patients, and was the first FDA-approved test using human neural stem cells (extracted, in this case, from aborted fetuses). So far, both Daniel Kerner and a second child who was treated are doing fine.   But because Batten disease affects just one in about 250,000, the treatment has no blockbuster potential -- one reason the shares have been dormant. CFO Rodney Young stresses, however, that the effort has "substantial impact" on the study of degenerative neural disorders. StemCells is also planning a clinical trial this year for liver disease.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) The Trader: Even The Bulls Aren't So Bullish
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   There are many ways to mark a milestone -- with champagne, a lavish party, a tattoo. A week after the Dow Jones Industrial Average hit 13,000, the Standard & Poor's 500 enjoyed its own big-round-number moment when it trudged above 1500, but its arrival was met with doubt.   The lack of jubilation was understandable. Consumer spending had increased 3.8% in the first quarter -- thank you, bonuses! -- but gas-pump prices topping $3 a gallon could make that harder to replicate this quarter. Friday's government report showing the jobless rate rising in April to 4.5%, and wary employers adding the fewest jobs in two- and-a-half years, also didn't help.   Money managers have recently been buying every dip, mindful of the market's abundant liquidity and anxious not to fall behind the robust rally that began mid-March. But stocks' advances grew tentative last week, and the question asked up and down Wall Street was whether stocks had run up too far too fast. Even a rash of mergers -- both real and speculated- that egged on buyers began to raise a nagging question: What happens if the merger mania cools?   Climbing for the fifth straight week, the Dow added 144, or 1.1%, to 13,265. It has risen in 23 of the past 26 days -- the longest such streak since 1944. The S&P 500 also rallied for a fifth straight week, and for the sixth time in seven weeks, adding 12, or 0.8%, to 1506. It stands just 1.4% from its March 2000 peak. The Nasdaq Composite Index added 15, or 0.6%, to a new six-year peak at 2572, while the Russell 2000 Index of small stocks snuck up 3, or 0.4%, to 833.   The Dow's recent outperformance certainly bears watching. "Blue chips tend to show relative strength late in sustained declines and late in sustained advances," notes Miller Tabak's chief technical analyst, Philip Roth. In a slipping market, investors return by nibbling at big, safe stocks, and large-cap outperformance can signal an impending upturn.   But after a long rise, still-confident investors who grow wary of high prices start taking profits in their broader portfolio and funnel those toward blue chips. "The longer the broader averages make little progress in an environment of blue-chip strength, the more likely a top is forming," Roth says.   To Barry Ritholtz, chief market strategist at Ritholtz Research & Analytics, the juxtaposition of rising stocks and a cooling economy makes this "a trading market, where momentum and trend dominate, increasingly detached from decaying domestic fundamentals." A melt-up to Dow 14,000 would not surprise, Ritholtz says, but that represents a risky "trading, not investing, opportunity."   Whether the rally is slowing -- or, as the bulls prefer, consolidating -- remains to be seen. For days, the benchmarks have made new highs on dwindling volume and waning leadership. Yet, sentiment is far from excessively bullish. In fact, short interest that is nearly 18% above a three-year average suggests there are skeptics, and money on the sidelines, that might still be converted.   Mark Boyar has lobbied for years for a sale of Dow Jones (DJ). But last week, as Dow Jones' stock jumped from 36 to 56 after a stunning $5 billion bid from News Corp. (NWS), the president of Boyar Asset Management promptly sold half of the nearly 300,000 shares he held.   Not that Boyar doesn't believe the odds are good that Rupert Murdoch, who controls News Corp., will wrest the publisher of Barron's and the Wall Street Journal from the Bancroft family, a sprawling clan that owns 25% of Dow Jones' shares but controls 64% of the voting rights. But with the stock up 56% to a five-year peak, the downside risks cannot be ignored.   Already, family members with 52% of the voting power had indicated that they opposed Murdoch's $60-a-share offer, which carried a staggering 65% premium rich enough to give rival suitors pause. If no better bid emerges, and if the Bancrofts can fend off Murdoch, the stock easily could fall back below 40. "And if it does, I'll buy back my position," Boyar says.   Right now, the market seems to regard a return trip to 40 as a possible but unlikely event. Shares held steady near 56 even after the Bancrofts said "no" -- a sign traders don't see the rebuff as final. Breathless media coverage has already flagged the likelihood of a sweetened bid from Murdoch, and the arrival of possible "white knights."   Forty-two million Dow Jones shares changed hands Tuesday -- the stock's busiest day in three decades -- and the crushing volume since then suggests shares increasingly are held by arbitrageurs angling for a deal. Pressure could mount on the independent board members to put the offer to a shareholder vote. In the days ahead, expect stories about the Bancrofts' fragile voting majority, the rift between older family members drinking from the dividend trough and younger heirs more eager to sell, and the waning allegiance to family businesses with the passing of generations.   An eventual sale of Dow Jones isn't considered a lock either. With shares at 56, Dow Jones' September 40 put options -- which ensure the right to sell shares at 40 over the next five months -- were priced at about $1.55, while September 35 puts were trading at $0.70. "These out-of-the-money puts would be almost worthless if the market believed a deal is a sure thing," says Citigroup derivatives strategist Andrew Wolchek.   In fact, option prices pegs the likelihood of a thwarted bid -- and the stock retreating below 40 -- to be between 25% and 30%, Wolchek estimates. The option market also sees a 20%-25% chance for a bid higher than 60. Meanwhile, June options are projecting an annualized volatility of 72%, compared with 49% projected by September options. That's a sign the market anticipates more noise and maneuvering over the next six weeks, before the uncertainty recedes by the fall.   For a man who hates to fly, Thomas Peterffy has amassed a geographically expansive empire -- an automated brokerage and market-making firm that trades 357,000 securities at more than 60 exchanges in 23 countries. Last week, the owner and founding CEO of Interactive Brokers Group tested public appetite for his company and was greeted with clamor.   IBG priced 40 million shares through an online auction at $30.01 a piece- near the top end of its recently-raised range between 27 and 31, and after IBG doubled the allotted shares in recent months. Shares (IBKR) debuted Friday at 33, and ended the session at 31.30. The deal valued the firm at $1.2 billion.   About $1 billion of the proceeds will go to Peterffy, an impeccably dressed and impossibly trim 62 year-old Hungarian immigrant. And he swelled his bank balance without relinquishing his stranglehold on the firm he founded 25 years ago, which he controls with 91.3% of voting rights post-IPO.   IBG has two main businesses: Timber Hill, a market-making firm that handles nearly one in every five listed option traded in the U.S. and one in every six globally; and Interactive Brokers, a low-cost electronic brokerage popular with active traders.   Net revenue grew 65% in 2005 and 35% last year, and the company keeps costs low with savvy use of automation. No surprise, then, to see shares accorded a plump valuation. At 31, IBG shares trade at a staggering 4.4 times tangible book value, or 26 times 2006 earnings of $1.21 per-share. That presupposes derivatives volume will keep growing at a galloping pace of more than 20% a year, and that Peterffy will continue to stay two nimble steps ahead of the crowd.   ---                       VITAL SIGNS                                 Friday's     Week's  Week's                                  Close     Change  % Chg. Headline: Barron's(5/7) Follow-Up: Offer Sweetened, Yet Deal Seems Doomed
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By andrew Bary   The $26 billion leveraged buyout of Clear Channel Communications is hanging by a very thin thread ahead of Tuesday's shareholder vote.   In a last-ditch effort to save the high-profile deal, a private-equity group led by Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital Partners last week lifted its offer to the company's public shareholders to $39.20 a share from $39 and said it would let them participate in the LBO. Late Thursday, Clear Channel's board rejected that proposalasstill too low. The company said proxies received so far show that more than one-third of holders are voting no, dooming the deal because it needs a two-thirds majority of outstanding shares.   Many shareholders believe that a public Clear Channel (ticker: CCU) is worth more than $42 a share, owing in part to the rising value of the company's billboard business, traded publicly as Clear Channel Outdoor Holdings (CCO). Clear Channel also has become a rallying point for institutional holders angry that private-equity firms have reaped big profits at their expense in prior LBOs. Two big shareholders, Fidelity Investment and Highfields Capital Management, which own a combined 15% of the stock, have opposed the deal.   It's conceivable that Clear Channel's board will reconsider its opposition to the new proposal if a sufficient number of large shareholders express support by Tuesday. The private-equity firms had planned to put $4 billion of equity into the deal. But after discussions with some dissidents, they decided to give about $1.2 billion, or 30%, to the public. This new equity wouldn't be subject to any fees from the private-equity group, actually making it a superior investment to the buyout firm's equity, according to a knowledgeable person.   The proposed equity available to public holders, however, is well short of Clear channel's current $18 billion equity value, meaning that any shareholder seeking to participate in that new proposal likely would get much more cash than stock. The new proposal would have offered the founding Mays family less -- $37.60 a share -- than the public holders' $39.20.   The betting on the Street is that the deal, originally announced in November, is dead and that Clear Channel's board, which appears tired of the long, acrimonious dispute over the buyout, will be content to run out the clock Tuesday.   Clear Channel shares moved up 40 cents, to $36.35, Friday, still well shy of the new bid by the buyout group. If investors and arbitragers had viewed board reconsideration of the new proposal likely, the shares probably would be above $37.   If the deal dies, there will be pressure on Clear Channel's management, led by CEO Mark Mays and President Randall Mays, to deliver for shareholders. Under a "Plan B", Bear Stearns analyst Victor Miller has written that Clear Channel could sell its international billboard business and then spin off the valuable domestic outdoor business to Clear Channel holders. Clear Channel's stake in Clear Channel Outdoor is worth about $18 per Clear Channel share. Miller values Clear Channel at $44 a share, before any steps to buy back stock by taking on added debt.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Accuride   -- ACW-NYSE     Underperform   -- Price 14.61 on April 30   by Baird Securities     Lowering [from Neutral] to Underperform . . . on this . . . original-equipment-manufacturer for the commercial-vehicle market. Cautious comments on second-half production [and] freight environment increase risk. 1Q EPS slightly below estimate, excluding commercial-dispute settlement . . . Net debt down 20%, year-over-year . . . Free cash flow remains strong. Net debt estimated to fall 20% by '08 . . . 12 target is based on stock trading at 5.2 times '08 [estimated earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, the median over last two years. [Watch] . . . pace of 2008-'09 recovery in demand, monthly orders.     Bankrate.com   -- RATE-NNM     Hold   -- Price 39.51 on May 2   by Needham & Co.     This Internet-based consumer-banking marketplace [offers] original editorial [and] aggregates information on about 300 financial products, including mortgages, credit cards, loans, [deposit products] and online banking fees . . . Revenues of $22.2 million were better than our $21.5 million estimate, but below Street mean, $23.2 million. Ebitda of $10 million [beat] our $8 million estimate . . . GAAP EPS of 27 cents [beat] our 20-cent estimate and Street mean, 22 cents . . . Lower-than-forecast [general and administrative] costs added 4 cents to EPS; better-than-expected gross margins added 2 cents.     Harris Corp.   -- HRS-NYSE     Underperform   -- Price 52.39 on May 1   by Prudential Securities     [Harris provides wireless communication and broadcast products and services for commercial and government markets.] RF Comm [battlefield-communications unit] results were better than we expected with . . . margin of 35.3%, compared with our estimate of 33%. Broadcast sales, however . . . [were lower than] we anticipated . . . Operating-profit growth rates could moderate from 10% growth in fiscal-year '08 based on our expectation that demand for RF products could slacken, assuming troop withdrawals from Iraq in 2008 and beyond. Estimated EPS for '07 is 2.80 and 3.30 for '08.     Hospitality Properties Trust   -- HPT-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 45.26 on May 2   by Wachovia Securities     HPT reported Q1 2007 [funds from operations per share] of $1.08 -- 6 to 7 cents ahead of our estimate and consensus. Strong[er]-than-anticipated net contribution from hotels/travel centers and lower interest expense was partially offset by slightly higher general/administrative costs and one-time costs associated with [TravelCenters of America] spin-off. Revenue per available room increased 4.1% on very strong rate growth and 2.8% decline in occupancy . . . difficult comparisons and softer results in the more limited-service product.     HouseValues   -- SOLD-NNM     Buy   -- Price 4.78 on May 2   by Think Equity     Reiterating Buy rating and lowering target from 7 to 6. SOLD continues to demonstrate weaker-than-expected fundamentals; average monthly customer churn rose on a percentage basis to 10.4% in 1Q07 from 9.3% in 4Q06 as SOLD continues to face a challenging macro environment. Although cost alignment returned SOLD to Ebitda profitability sooner than expected, we now [think it will] experience continued net agent attrition through FY07, reducing our FY07 and FY08 outlook. However . . . with roughly $3 per share in cash, we believe that risk-reward remains attractive.     Infinity Property & Casualty Insurance   -- IPCC-NNM     Outperform   -- Price 47.28 on May 2   by Morgan Keegan     Infinity reported very good operating results, with a year-over-year comparison of $1.05 versus $1.38. Q107 included only $1.1 million of favorable-reserve development (3 cents per share) versus $19 million of favorable development in Q106 (59 cents per share). Gross written premium was up 17.2% for the quarter, with growth in California, Arizona and Texas important contributors. The California growth of 22.5% was favorably influenced by electronic enforcement of mandatory insurance coverage. The Q107 GWP advance was slightly better than Q406 and represents the strongest quarter since Infinity went public in early 2003. We note that management's execution of the business plan it presented to investors at that time has been nearly flawless. Book value rose to $34.87 per share and the company purchased about 188,000 shares during the quarter under its $100 million repurchase program. Management guidance was raised moderately to $3.35-$3.75 per share for 2007. Our FY:2007 estimate remains $4.     Jones Lang LaSalle   -- JLL-NYSE     Strong Buy   -- Price 106.58 on May 2   by JMP Securities     The property firm reported . . . 45% revenue growth and EPS of 74 cents (excluding one-time benefits), compared to our 14-cent estimate and the 1Q06 figure of 12 cents . . . [on] generally attractive market conditions[including] healthy-advisory fee growth, and increased headcount. The [Europe, Middle East and Africa] region was particularly strong . . . [but] timing of transactions also contributed to revenue growth; we are adjusting our 2Q07 projections down slightly to account for this . . . while 1Q07 EPS grew from 14 cents to 74 cents, we are assuming just 22% EPS growth for remainder of the year. Our '08 EPS estimate is lifted from $6.10 to $6.50 . . . Our target, 130 [raised from 122], assumes . . . a forward price/earnings multiple of 20 times at this time next year.     Landauer   -- LDR-NYSE     Long-Term Buy   -- Price 51.62 on May 2   by Hilliard Lyons     Landauer is the world's largest provider of personnel radiation-monitoring services. The company provides radiation dosimetry services to hospitals, universities, nuclear power plants, and many small offices in the U.S. and in foreign markets. Lower-than-expected spending resulted in second fiscal quarter earnings well above our estimate.   Earnings for the quarter were 65 cents a share, up 5% from 62 cents per share last year, excluding nonrecurring items . . . Revenue for the quarter rose 5% to $21.6 million from $20.6 million last year. Sales were in line with expectations. . . . We now look for flat earnings in fiscal 2007. The expected level of spending on new information systems and increased revenue will apparently be less than first thought. Consequently, we have raised our fiscal 2007 EPS estimate by 10 cents, to $2.20, even with $2.20 in fiscal 2006, excluding restructuring charges and costs for management transition. We've changed rating to Long-term Buy from Buy. Despite modest growth prospects, Landauer has typically traded at a premium valuation. We feel this is due to its high margins, reliable revenue, and attractive yield. Our 60 target assumes resuming growth in '08 and sustaining current valuation as earnings exceed $2.50 in two to three years.     Omniture   -- OMTR-NNM     Sector Perform   -- Price 18.29 on May 1   by Pacific Crest     Omniture is a leading provider of on-demand Web analytics and digital marketing solutions. Q1 results [were] ahead of expectations. Omniture reported non-GAAP revenue and EPS of $29.5 million and 2 cents, compared with our consensus estimates of $27.9 million and (a loss of 1 cent). The upside was driven by continued robust demand for Web analytics and strength in Omniture's products, as well as international acquisitions closed in the quarter and a large deal with AOL. Growth remains strong, but investments cloud earnings outlook. We expect Omniture's above-average growth to continue because of its heavy investing in sales personnel, marketing, research and development, international expansion and technology platform. However, these investments will limit leverage in the model in 2007 and lower visibility on longer-term growth in EPS and free cash flow, in our view.     Rowan Cos.   -- RDC-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 36.65 on May 2   by Sterne Agee     [Houston-based offshore driller] Rowan Cos. reported operating 1Q07 EPS of 70 cents, versus 53 cents in 1Q06. Our estimate [and consensus] was 69 cents . . . Special items included 14 cents per share on an asset-sale gain, offset by a loss of 7 cents per share on new construction of the Panueo, a rig built for Perforadora Central, a Mexican rig owner. Offshore fleet utilization was 84% and was low due to a number of rig moves during the quarter. Close to full utilization should occur in 2Q07. . . . Day rates for shallow-water jackups in the Gulf of Mexico appear to be in recovery...Maintaining Buy, but raising 12-month target from 43 to 45 . . . [which] equates to 9.7, 5.4 and 7.1 times our 2007E EPS, Ebitda and cash flow from operations, respectively. These metrics are at discounts to the group . . . Our EPS estimate for 2Q07 is raised from $1.12 to $1.15. Our 2007 EPS estimate is raised from $4.60 to $4.64.     WebMD Health   -- WBMD-NNM     Hold   -- Price 50.96 on May 2   by Maxim Group     WBMD reports 1Q07 results ahead of its guidance and expectations; 2H07 outlook stronger than expected; company raises guidance; valuation improving, but still a little rich; raising estimates; initiating 12-month price target of 53; maintain Hold.   We continue to recommend that investors gain exposure to the paradigm shift in health-care marketing spending toward the Web and to the adoption of consumer-driven health-care plans through WBMD and its parent, Emdeon Corp (HLTH). However, we continue to believe that current valuation, although now more attractive (the stock has declined about11% over past two to three weeks), reflects the company's near-term growth potential. Our new fair-value estimate for WBMD is 46 and our 12-month price target is 53.     Yum! Brands   -- YUM-NYSE     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: =WSJ: Buffett Defends Donations To Planned Parenthood
Story: By Karen Richardson     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     OMAHA, Neb. (Dow Jones)--Inspiring cheers from among a crowd of 27,000 shareholders, billionaire Warren Buffett Saturday defended his charitable contribution to organizations that support women's reproductive rights, such as Planned Parenthood.   Buffett was responding to a question from a shareholder from St. James, N.Y., during the annual meeting of his Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (BRKA) holding company.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   The shareholder, who said he brought one of his five daughters to the meeting in Omaha, asked Buffett to explain why he supports organizations such as Planned Parenthood. "It just doesn't seem to jibe with the hero that I studied," the shareholder told Buffett amid boos from the audience.   "Men set the rules for a lot of years, and I think it's wonderful that women can make reproductive choices," Buffett replied, as shareholders applauded and cheered.   Buffett announced in June 2006 that he would pledge some 85% of his Berkshire stake, amounting to about $44 billion at the current stock price, to five charities, the largest of which is the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. His Buffett Foundation, which for decades was run by Buffett's late first wife, Susan, long supported projects that promoted a woman's right to birth control and abortion, as well as population control in developing countries.   "I think it's a terrific organization," Buffett added, referring to Planned Parenthood. "I really think it's too bad that for millennia, women not only in the U.S. but all over the world, have had involuntary bearing of babies."     -By Karen Richardson, The Wall Street Journal; karen.richardson@wsj.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 14:51 ET (18:51 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/7) Speaking Of Dividends: Bubbling Over: Profitable PepsiCo Offers Investors Zesty Payout
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   Pepsico is pepping up its payout for the 35th year in a row. The beverage and snack-food giant sweetened its quarterly common dividend 25% Wednesday, to 37.5 cents a share from 30 cents. Disbursement is slated for June 29 to stockholders of record June 8. The ex-dividend date is June 6.   The action, which was a result of PepsiCo's increasing its dividend payout target to 50% of the prior year's earnings, gives the shares a 2.23% yield. Dividends have been ongoing since 1952.   The Purchase, N.Y.-based company, whose corporate roots reach back to 1916, also enriched its stock-buyback program by $8 billion through mid-2010. That'll kick in when Pepsi wraps up its $8.5-billion plan begun in 2006, which has $6 billion left to go. It expects to repurchase $4.3 billion worth of its stock in 2007.   Chief executive Indra K. Nooyi said the announcements "reflect our continued confidence in the growth of our business and our steadfast commitment to providing strong cash returns to our shareholders." She said Pepsi has a "rich acquisition pipeline" and that deals could range from $5 million to $2 billion.   The stock (ticker: PEP) set a 52-week high of 67.72 on the Big Board Thursday. Archrival Coca-Cola (KO), a Dow industrials component, set a 52-week high Friday of 53.32, raised its quarterly three cents in February to 34 cents a share-its 45th annual hike -and yields 2.56%. Coke expects to repurchase as much as $3 billion of its stock this year. Standard & Poor's rates both issues Buy.   With 2006 revenues topping $35 billion, Pepsi's product roster includes 17 brands that generate $1 billion or more each in annual retail sales. Chief among them, besides its carbonated offerings, are Frito-Lay snacks, Gatorade sports drinks, Tropicana juices, Quaker foods and Aquafina water. Pepsi's first-quarter results exceeded Wall Street's estimates, with profits climbing 16% from a year earlier, to $1.1 billion, or 65 cents a share, on a 9% revenue gain, to $7.35 billion.   The nation's No. 1 source of home mortgages, Fannie Mae (FNM), publicly owned but operating under federal charter, finances more than one in five U.S.home loans. Back in January 2005, it halved its dividend to 26 cents a share to help rebuild capital depleted by losses on derivatives contracts used to hedge interest-rate risk. In December 2006, its dividend  started climbing with an increase in payout of 54%, to 40 cents a share.   Last Wednesday the quarterly was enriched again, by 25%, to 50 cents a share. The respective payment and record dates are May 25 and May 18, and the stock goes ex-dividend May 16. Yield: 2.60%. Fannie Mae has paid dividends since 1956. The home-mortgage lender's shares trade on the Big Board close to their 52-week high of 62.37, set Nov. 8.   Also last week, federal regulators said they will distribute roughly $400 million by October to Fannie Mae stockholders hurt by the company's alleged accounting fraud. Investors may be eligible if they bought Fannie Mae common between Jan. 14, 1999, and Dec. 22, 2004, or Class N preferred stock from Sept. 25, 2003, to Dec. 22, 2004. Fannie Mae just reported 2005 net of $6.3 billion, or $6.01 a share, versus 2004's $5 billion, or $4.94. It expects to post 2006 results later this year.   When Felix Zulauf, one of Barron's Roundtable luminaries, again listed Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) among his picks in mid-January, the stock was around 144. It set a 52-week high of 193.79 April 26 and is now around 187. Wednesday Potash declared a 3-for-1 stock split and doubled its quarterly common dividend to a pre-split 30 cents a share (10 cents post-split), its first hike since July 2004. Potash's share price has surged 280% on the Big Board since its previous split, in August 2004.   The world's largest fertilizer company, Potash -- which Barron's wrote about on Nov. 6, 2006 -- earned a record $198 million, or $1.85 a share, in the first quarter of 2007, on a 34% jump in sales, to $1.15 billion. Fertilizer demand is strong worldwide, and supplies are tight. Thus, Potash has boosted its 2007 earnings estimate to $7.50-$8.50 a share from an earlier $6.25 to $7.25. It earned $5.95 in 2006.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: WSJ: RBS Consortium Makes Bid For LaSalle - Sources
Story: (Updates with details)       By Carrick Mollenkamp and Jason Singer     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     The European banking consortium seeking to make a bid for Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding NV (ABN) Saturday afternoon made a conditional $24.5 billion bid for ABN's LaSalle Bank unit, after scrambling in the past 24 hours to finalize a memo outlining the proposal, according to people familiar with the situation.   The consortium, led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS.LN) and chief executive Fred Goodwin, made the bid ahead of a Sunday deadline. The offer is higher than Bank of America Corp.'s (BAC) offer of $21 billion. But it also includes some conditions.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   The RBS team considers the conditions to be allowable under ABN's contract with Bank of America over the LaSalle sale. But as it stands, ABN may not judge the new LaSalle bid to be superior to Bank of America's.   The LaSalle bid isn't subject to financing and the group already has the cash in hand for that purchase, people close to the matter said. But among the conditions attached to that bid is that the consortium gets an agreement over a full takeover bid for all of ABN.   The proposal submitted to ABN today lacked full details on the consortium's financing arrangements for the full bid, people close to the matter said. However, the financing will be settled by the Sunday deadline, other people involved in the situation said, highlighting that the three banks' boards of directors have already approved the arrangements and the final documents are just waiting for a takeover agreement with ABN before they are signed.   The RBS-led group has said its bid for ABN would be 70% cash and 30% in RBS shares. But the other two consortium banks - Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano SA (STD) and Dutch-Belgian concern Fortis NV (FORSY) - aren't expected to begin fundraising until the fourth quarter, the people close to the matter said. That could raise questions for ABN shareholders whether financing is secure.   Additionally, the proposal for LaSalle is conditional on ABN settling the various lawsuits brought against it as a result of its contract to sell LaSalle to Bank of America.   But on Friday, Bank of America filed a lawsuit against ABN seeking to enforce its agreement to buy LaSalle. That deal stemmed from ABN's earlier agreement to be bought by the U.K.'s Barclays PLC (BCS) for $89.9 billion in stock, which is contingent on LaSalle being sold.   The RBS consortium's offer is the first stage of a weekend-long series of discussions. ABN officials said they are trying to be flexible in working with the RBS consortium. Morale between ABN and the European banking group trying to top the Dutch bank's agreed deal to be acquired by Barclays has dramatically improved, people from both camps say.   ABN and the RBS consortium had been engaged in "collaborative" talks, with several working groups toiling around the clock to assist the Royal Bank team in coming up with a firm rival bid valued at about EUR39 a share, or EUR72.27 billion ($98 billion), people familiar with the situation said.   Either bid for ABN would mark the world's largest banking deal, and one of the most complex. The Royal Bank proposal includes carving up ABN's various businesses around the world between it and its two partners, Fortis and Banco Santander Central Hispano. A breakup of a bank on this scale has never been tried before.     -By Carrick Mollenkamp and Jason Singer, The Wall Street Journal; Carrick.Mollenkamp@wsj.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 16:16 ET (20:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Japan Elec Utilities To Open 8 LNG Pwr Plants By 2012 -Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--Electric power companies around the country are constructing and upgrading power stations fueled by liquefied natural gas, The Nikkei reported in its Sunday edition.   With eight LNG facilities scheduled to be built over the next five years, the ratio of LNG-produced power to all thermal power generation will jump to 47% from the current 43%, slashing carbon dioxide emissions by almost 10%.   Thermal power plants account for nearly 30% of all emissions of CO2 and other greenhouse gases in Japan.  The electric utility industry has set a target of slashing CO2 emissions per kilowatt of power generation by 20% from the fiscal 1990 level by fiscal 2010.   Because LNG contains less carbon than other types of energy, increasing the ratio of LNG power generation is an effective way to reduce CO2 emissions.  LNG stations emit 40%-50% less CO2 per unit of generated power than coal-burning plants and 20%-30% less than oil-fired facilities.   Shikoku Electric Power Co. (9507.TO) plans to start building its first LNG power plant, in Kagawa Prefecture in October, by converting an oil-powered station located there, aiming to have the facility go online in August 2010.  The conversion will lift the output capacity of the plant by 50%.  The company intends to begin converting another oil plant into an LNG power station in fiscal 2009.   Okinawa Electric Power Co. (9511.TO), which currently has no LNG power plants, intends to begin construction of two facilities in June, targeting the start of operations between 2010 and 2011. The only utility among the nation's 10 electric power companies without a nuclear plant depends on coal and oil to generate almost all its power.  After the new LNG plants go onstream, the ratio of coal and oil generation will fall to two-thirds.   In five years, Hokkaido Electric Power Co. (9509.TO) and Hokuriku Electric Power Co. (9505.TO) will be the only domestic utilities without LNG power plants.   Other firms are expanding their LNG power generation, with Chugoku Electric Power Co. (9504.TO) and Tohoku Electric Power Co. (9506.TO) planning to convert aging coal thermal power stations in Okayama Prefecture and Miyagi Prefecture, respectively, to LNG plants.   Tokyo Electric Power Co. (9501.TO) intends to upgrade an LNG power plant in Kawasaki, Kanagawa Prefecture, while Kansai Electric Power Co. (9503.TO) aims to do the same for an LNG power station in Osaka Prefecture.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 14:13 ET (18:13 GMT)

Headline: UPDATE: Kenya Airways Plane Crashed In S Cameroon-State Radio
Story: (Updates number on board, location of crisis center is at hotel)     YAOUNDE, Cameroon (AP)--A Kenya Airways passenger plane with more than 100 people on board crashed in southern Cameroon on Saturday, state radio reported.   The west African nation's radio report said that the Nairobi-bound jet went down near the town of Niete, north of the border with Equatorial Guinea. It gave no further details.   Kenya Airways CEO Titus Naikuni, speaking in Nairobi, said he couldn't immediately confirm the radio report that the plane had crashed. "We have not been officially informed," he said.   Relatives waiting at Nairobi's airport began wailing when television news stations reported that the plane had crashed. Dozens of family members cried and collapsed in the airport terminal while awaiting official word from the airline.   Naikuni said a team of investigators had been dispatched to the crash site but "so far no report has been received yet from this mission."   Kenya Airways (KAL.NR) said earlier Saturday it had lost contact with the jet shortly after its midnight takeoff from Douala, Cameroon, north of Niete.   "The last message was received in Douala after takeoff and thereafter the tower was unable to contact the plane," Naikuni said.   Kenyan airline officials said the Boeing 737-800 was carrying 114 people, including 105 passengers, from 23 countries. Naikuni said the plane was six months old.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 05, 2007 06:51 ET (10:51 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
